name: Presidente. –
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday, 13 December 2018.

name: Presidente. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, unfortunately, two hours ago we learned that Paweł Adamowicz, mayor of Danzińsk, did not survive yesterday's attack. Those who knew him remember his dedication to the service of citizens and his great openness and listening skills. On behalf of the European Parliament, I would like to express our condolences and our closeness to the family and to the whole city of Danzin. A month ago, the cowardly attack on Europe's heart in Strasbourg cost the lives of Pascal Verden, Kamal Nagchband, Anupong Suebsamarn, Antonio Megalizzi and Barto Pedro Orent-Niedzielski. Unfortunately, we are once again crying out as victims of hatred, extremism and radicalisation in Europe. The European Union was born first of all to guarantee peace and combat all forms of violence, yet just a few months before the elections in May, we are seeing increasing tension in several Member States. There have been attacks on political representatives in the UK, Germany and Hungary in recent weeks. There have also been disturbing incidents of anti-Semitism in football stadiums, but it is not enough to condemn these incidents firmly, we need everyone to take responsibility. The debate between ideas and opinions, which is at the heart of democracy, must take place with respect for the adversary, who must never be turned into an enemy. All too often we have experienced how verbal violence can result in physical violence. We must have a different language, eliminating any incitement to hatred, which is not compatible with the model of peaceful coexistence of our Union. My appeal is for everyone to lower their tone, even on social media. The attack in Strasbourg shows that we cannot let our guard down. The European Parliament will continue to fight relentlessly against terrorism of all kinds and we will not forget any of the victims. This week, as many of you have requested, I will discuss with the Mayor of Strasbourg how we can pay tribute to the victims in December. As early as this evening, I will be proposing to the Bureau that our radio studio be named after the two journalists killed in the attack, Antonio Megalizzi and Barto Pedro Orent-Niedzielski. (Parliament was standing and observing a minute's silence)

name: Janusz Lewandowski (PPE).
text: – Mr President, thank you for your Twitter message and your words now when there is no longer any hope. What happened in Gdańsk is a personal tragedy for a very popular, newly re-elected mayor of Gdańsk, Paweł Adamowicz.  He was my friend, a good man and a man of both patriotic and European values. This is a tragedy for his family and a deep shock for the community of Gdańsk, which was gathering yesterday on the occasion of a normally very joyful and spectacular charity event in Gdańsk. But this is something more. You are completely right, because here in Strasbourg is the living memory of a terrorist attack – a fresh memory. Too often in today’s Europe acts of hatred and fanaticism replace dialogue, tolerance and friendly coexistence beyond our differences. We should reflect upon this.  (Applause)

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Mr President, yes, indeed. On behalf of the S&D Group, and also because I knew him personally, I need also to tell you something about the meaning of this terrible murder of the Mayor of Gdańsk, Mr Paweł Adamowicz. I knew him as an outstanding local leader, a mayor elected several times, and someone who really represented and was a symbol of an open society, able to deal with strong support on human rights, and also defending minorities wherever they are. I remember him saying, in a difficult situation, that yes, Gdańsk will be in a position to receive refugees in need of protection and asylum in Europe. And this is just an example of the kind of things he was able to deliver. So yes, it is really shocking that all of a sudden all the arguments we need to have in democratic institutions are just replaced by knives in an ugly murder. This is something we cannot accept. And let me be clear: we will stand behind those who are in favour of an open society and defending human rights, whatever the price. (Applause)

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as you mentioned earlier, today is a day of mourning and sadness for many reasons. Exactly a month ago Antonio Megalizzi, the victim, together with his friend and colleague Barto Pedro Orent-Niedzielski, of a bloody and unacceptable fanaticism, was missing. Their commitment and enthusiasm cannot and must not be forgotten, many colleagues and delegations have expressed their desire to commemorate them in recent days. That is why Mr Krasnodębski and I, in addition to the initiative and your previous proposal to name them the radio station, which we support and support, also intend to propose the establishment of a scholarship for young European journalists dedicated to them, financed by Parliament itself and named after both victims, because these victims, journalism and a passion for European politics, had consecrated their lives thanks to the Europhonica project. We would like to allow the values and passion of these young people, my peers, to continue to walk on the legs of other young European journalists. We trust in the broad support of all Members and groups in this Parliament, and with this small gesture we want to reiterate that reason and the rule of law in Europe are not and will never be defeated by violence and extremism.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, I too, on behalf of my group, would like to join with those colleagues who have spoken about the death of the mayor of Gdansk, as well as the murder of the Italian journalist a few weeks ago in Strasbourg. I believe that, regardless of our political differences, all wings of the European Parliament must be united in the defence of democracy, tolerance, the rule of law, pluralism and against hatred, violence and racism.

name: Presidente. –
text: Mr Toia, Mr Wałęsa, Mr Monteiro, Mr Țapardel have asked for the floor.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! Pawel Adamowicz was murdered. He became a victim of hatred, but he also became a victim of hate speech. We need to think about how to limit and throw this behaviour out of public debate. I would like to remind you that this tragedy happened during a charity concert. Pawel Adamowicz spoke a moment earlier about fraternity, about solidarity, about the fact that we should give ourselves to another man, and a moment later he was stabbed – by this hatred, by this language of hatred. I wanted to tell you that Gdańsk lost a great local patriot, but we all also lost a great European, because Paweł Adamowicz understood that both of them were not contradictory, that we could be local patriots and that we could build a better common Europe. Let's remember him like that!

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to join in the words of the President and all of you in expressing my condolences to the Mayor of Danzig and, quite rightly, I remember those who died a few weeks ago right here in Strasbourg. Today, however, I would like to say to all of you, because many may not know, that Cesare Battisti, a terrorist who for too many years has enjoyed the cover of so many governments, not just Europeans, has finally been brought to justice in Italy. I hope that the terrorists, all the terrorists, will be brought to justice and that the French government will return to Italy those terrorists who, unfortunately, still enjoy the cover of that government.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The assassination of President Pawel Adamowicz is an example of great barbarism. This is a very great tragedy for all of us. It is a great evil that arouses anger, sorrow and condemnation. We should consider how to throw evil out of public spaces, how to condemn hatred. We should consider what we can do to make public debate calmer, what we can do to keep Europe's streets safe.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, recalling the emotion of that night that we spent at the last part-session, right here in this House with you, who gave us news, we were all so shocked and impressed, while in the city Antonio, the young colleague and other victims were barbarically affected, I will be very brief. I would like to remind you that the proposal was made, and you were immediately involved in it, in the aftermath of this event, in the aftermath of Antonio's death, especially by our group, in particular by Silvia Costa in her capacity as the leading member of the Committee on Culture and Education, who had known and collaborated, like many of us, with this boy and with his network of university radio stations. That proposal, which is being taken up today, has been put forward and is excellent. Scholarships and the naming of a press room, because these guys used their profession, their aspiration to the journalistic profession, you called it back, precisely to carry on values and I say to all our colleagues that we should be united in remembering them, also remembering that the best way to remember the sacrifice of Antonio and his colleague, is to be truly Pro-European too. , every day and in every action, and not just in public discourse.

name: Marcel de Graaff (ENF).
text: Mr President, on behalf of my group, I would also like to express our condolences in connection with the terrible murder of Pawel Adamowicz. These are things that shock not only Poland, but I think every parliament in the EU. Unfortunately, it's not the first, and I'm afraid it won't be the last either. What we are seeing is a political atmosphere in the EU that has become increasingly louder over the years. The debate is no longer held in the plenary chamber, but on the streets. And whether it's in a theatre or the yellow hedges, I think the message to politics is that instead of just calling the ears shut, we should also listen to what the other person has to say. Perhaps that will help to end that atmosphere of hatred, which is always created in this chamber.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE).
text: – Mr President, it is also an issue of high relevance and timeliness, and I therefore believe that Parliament must also condemn another chapter in The history of Venezuela that is sharpening the dramatic crisis in which the country has been plunged. Even with the rejection of the international community, Nicolas Maduro took office with a second term and I believe that the European Parliament should pass a resolution declaring Maduro's government illegitimate and proposes new presidential elections. It is a dramatic situation that has been going on for four years, with a lack of medicines and people fleeing the country. We are talking about three million Venezuelans who have left the country out of fear, who have left the country for violence and lack of conditions. We are talking about a failed state, we are talking about a state that has forced lusodescendants and Venezuelans to return, also to my island, to Madeira, and so I do not think it is enough just to support them in our countries, we have to assert the voice of the Venezuelan people and we must also support them here in Europe.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to raise a very important issue affecting the future of tens of thousands of families and children in Romania, but also throughout Central and Eastern Europe, and I believe that both the European Parliament and the European Commission must take a stand as soon as possible to address this problem. From 1 January 2019, a law has entered into force in Austria whereby the allowances of children from Romania and all over Central and Eastern Europe and whose parents work in Austria have been considerably reduced by adjusting them to the standard of living in the Community countries where these children live. Such a measure cannot be allowed in a Member State of the European Union, where the rights of European citizens are enshrined in the European Treaties and, in particular, if we are talking – and in this case we are talking – about a measure that affects the future, education and development of our children. I also find it revolting that, although these workers who come from Central and Eastern Europe contribute to the national social system in Austria, they pay taxes in Austria, they do not receive the same benefits as Austrian citizens. That is why I call on both the European Commission and the European Parliament to react accordingly. The European Commission has a duty to sanction this arbitrary law, which affects the future of tens of thousands of children, and I believe that we cannot accept such a situation.

name: El presidente. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Norbert Lins and Bart Staes, on behalf of the Special Commission on the Union Authorisation Procedure for Pesticides, on the Union authorisation procedure for pesticides (2018/2153(INI))(A8-0475/2018).

name: Norbert Lins
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Today we are discussing measures to ensure the health of our 500 million citizens in Europe. Parliament's special committee has thoroughly scrutinised the EU's authorisation procedure for plant protection products. Protection for the user and the consumer was our highest priority in the preparation of the report now before us.  I grew up on a farm myself, i used pesticides when I was young, so I know how important the right application is and the importance of plant protection products for agriculture. At the same time, I want your and my children to continue to be able to eat fruit and vegetables from Europe without worry. Two questions have therefore been of particular concern to me during this special committee. Firstly, how do we continue to ensure that the food on the table in Europe is safe? Secondly, how do we ensure that our European farmers can produce these foods in the long term?  After nine months of thorough consideration, what have we found? Three times you can advise: that the EU's authorisation procedure is the strictest in the world! Good news. But the principle always applies: even the best can still improve. Our motto was therefore: evolution instead of revolution, development instead of overthrow. In order not to reinvent the wheel, our focus was therefore on three points: firstly, science, secondly, transparency and independence, and thirdly, innovation. Firstly, science. For me, it was and is crucial that the authorisation procedure is science-based. On such an important issue, scientific research is the be-all and end-all. In my view, interests or ideologies have no place here. This decision must not depend on day-to-day politics or emotion. Secondly, independence and transparency. It is crucial that the procedure remains independent and transparent. In future, therefore, the EU Commission, and no longer industry, will decide which Member State is responsible for testing an active substance. This strengthens the independence of the process. It also aims to increase public access to studies, while at the same time preserving the competitiveness of our European industry. Thirdly, innovation. I want to encourage innovation. New, more efficient products are the key to a more sustainable application. This must be supported by a smooth authorisation procedure. Allow me to take a brief look into the future: the way agriculture looks will once again be radically changed by digitalisation. It contributes to the farmer's need for less resources. We have to stay on the ball here. Conclusion: We in Parliament have dealt intensively with the European authorisation procedures for plant protection products. I am convinced that our recommendations will make our European authorisation procedure more efficient, transparent and robust. Why? We create a high level of protection for consumers and users. At the same time, we guarantee reliable processes for industry and agriculture and promote innovation. Let us launch these recommendations by a large majority on Wednesday. I would like to thank my co-rapporteur, Bart Staes, very warmly for the good cooperation and also for all the other shadow rapporteurs. I look forward to the vote on Wednesday and now the discussion.

name: Bart Staes
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, 1,070,865 citizens have asked us, through a European Citizens' Initiative, among other things, to look at the decision-making process on the authorisation of pesticides and to reform it. This report by the Union Special Committee on Pesticides admissions procedure shows that we take this question seriously. I am very satisfied with the result. It is essentially about restoring public confidence in our decision-making procedures. Citizens should be able to blindly trust that when we make a decision, it is done in the name of the public interest and not in the name of the private interest of private individuals, private organisations or industry. Here are some of the recommendations.  What Mr Lins, my co-rapporteur, said is true: we recognise that the current decision-making mechanism is one of the strictest in the world. However, improvements are possible, both on the regulation and on implementation. The basic principles are, firstly, the application of the precautionary principle and, secondly, ensuring that the decision-making procedure on pesticides is transparent, independent and objective. Only then will we be able to regain the trust of European citizens.  As far as glyphosate is concerned, our committee says that the controversy over this has not yet been resolved. We have not been able to resolve this in our committee, but that is why we are asking the Commission's scientific advisory mechanism – which has even offered this – to carry out a systematic evaluation of all available studies on the carcinogenic or potentially carcinogenic properties of glyphosate, so that a review of the current authorisation is necessary.  Transparency and independence. Transparency: we want to oblige the applicant to include all studies in the public register. We want to ensure access to that register for all citizens, so that they can consult all supporting data, all studies and in such a way that independent scientists can also check whether the correct procedures have been followed and the right conclusions have been drawn. We also ask the Member States and the Commission for full transparency when it comes to the functioning of the Standing Committee to which the Member States come to decisions. We want a transparent overview of the minutes. We want full disclosure of voting.  As far as independence is concerned, we as a committee want the applicant to no longer be allowed to designate the rapporteur Member State himself: only the Commission can do so. And only Those Member States which have sufficient technical scientific expertise, have the resources and also have internal procedures in place to avoid conflicts of interest may be designated as rapporteur Member States. Moreover, we want sufficient resources to be provided for EFSA and ECHA in such a way that they can guarantee and guarantee full independence. We also ask Horizon to fund programmes for independent research into both the impact on human and animal health and the impact on the environment.  Finally, there is the problem of possible plagiarism. The fact that the rapporteur-Member State is taking over evaluations, copy-paste of the applicant, and which is reflected in the final report without attribution. We want this takeover of data to be done as little as possible. And if it happens at all, that it happens correctly and is also indicated as that.  In our report, particular attention is paid to the long-term effects, the ecotoxicological effects of pesticides, the impact on weak groups, cocktail use, the synergistic effects of pesticide use and multiple pesticides at the same time, and the cumulative effect.  In addition, we want the cut-off criteria of Article 5 to be applied unabated. We have found that this is not always the case. We also want to include the whole discussion about endocrine disruptors. We also want glyphosate not to be used in parks, public gardens, sports and recreation areas, school grounds, playgrounds and areas close to care facilities. Finally, Article 53 is the article providing for exceptions. This article is now widely used as a permanent exception. The exception should be exception, nothing more and nothing less. Finally, to Mrs Hazekamp of the GUE/NGL Group: we must apply the three V's in the field of animal testing. We have to reduce it, we have to avoid it and we have to replace it.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, yes, of course, European citizens expect safe and healthy food – and rightly so. However, while ensuring food safety remains an imperative, it is no longer sufficient in itself. Increasingly, citizens have concerns about how their food is produced, about the sustainability of the food system and about environmental protection. We can only meet these expectations if we come together, learn lessons from recent challenges and move forward in the interests of all citizens. In this context, I would like to thank your House for having set up this excellent Special Committee on the Union’s authorisation procedure for pesticides (PEST) last year, notably following the Commission’s report on the implementation of the Directive on the Sustainable Use of Pesticides, the European Citizens’ Initiative and the debate on glyphosate. The Committee’s work is very important as we all aim to ensure transparency and an evidence—based food safety system, dispelling any doubts European citizens may have as to the neutrality of science, because the main challenge is how we can we guarantee that the science is excellent, perfect and neutral, and not biased. So I am pleased to have this opportunity to discuss the PEST Committee’s report with you today. This Special Committee was set up in December 2017, following the renewal of glyphosate’s approval for a further five years. Its mandate was to analyse the current EU system of approval for active substances and authorisation of plant protection products. It was also asked to identify areas for possible improvements. One of the key outcomes of the PEST Committee’s assessment is the need to restore trust in the EU system, in particular trust in the scientific evaluation of a substance and trust in the risk management phase. A high level of transparency is critical to this: firstly, making all studies used as a basis for risk assessment publicly available, and, secondly, the utmost transparency on discussions and positions held in the regulatory committee which decides which active substances to approve. I think that it is safe to say that we have come a long way since last year. The Commission’s proposal of April 2018 on the transparency and sustainability of EU risk assessment in the food chain aims to rebuild trust in the system. It addresses many of the PEST Committee’s recommendations, notably, firstly, transparency during risk assessment, secondly, the quality and reliability of studies, and, thirdly, improving risk communication. As I already stressed last December during our debate on the proposal for a revision of the General Food Law, European citizens have expressed in recent years such a clear and repeated demand for more transparency in the way risk assessments are conducted and I have been carefully listening to them and active since the beginning of my mandate on this issue. I have also carefully read the resolution on glyphosate that you voted on a year ago, where you stressed that the European Union’s authorisation procedure, including the scientific evaluation of substances, should be based only on published studies. I believe that it is through greater transparency that we will increase the confidence of citizens in the risk assessment system. Transparency can help us to avoid potential bias in science. It is crucial to improve trust in the EU evidence-based food safety system and in science in general. I am confident that, when adopted, this proposal will greatly help in this respect. On this proposal, I thank you once again for your plenary vote last month and for the constructive first trilogue, which I am pleased took place this afternoon. Given the importance of this issue for European citizens, I know you will work actively to make progress in the discussions with the Council to allow an agreement to be found in this legislative term. You can, of course, count on me and my services to work energetically with you to achieve this objective in our role as an honest broker, and I know that DG SANTE and the PEST Committee have had a very good collaboration in the whole period of building this report. This would allow the new Regulation to apply as soon as possible, including in the pesticides sector. But, even before this proposal, in the area of pesticides, I had taken a number of steps to increase citizens’ trust in the decision-making and risk management process. For the most sensitive files, such as glyphosate, neonicotinoids and endocrine disruptors, the Commission now has dedicated websites. These sites list all the different versions of the draft proposals and detailed minutes of the discussions held with Member States. Equally, the Commission receives a high number of requests for access to documents on pesticides. Since last April, all documents to which access is given have been made publicly available. In addition, with the proposal revising the Comitology Regulation, the Commission aims to increase voting transparency at the Appeal Committee level, making the votes of Member States’ representatives public. In its report, the PEST Committee rightly notes that the EU has one of the most stringent systems in the world to regulate pesticides, but that, of course, it needs to be improved. I agree. There is no such thing as a perfect system. It is always possible to improve procedures to approve active substances and authorisations of plant protection products. With this in mind, we are currently carrying out a Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme (REFIT) to evaluate our pesticide legislation. This includes both the Regulation on Plant Protection Products and the Regulation on Pesticide Residues and will soon be finalised. Its objective is to identify areas where improvements are needed. I want to take this opportunity to welcome the Parliament’s focus on this issue. In addition to the PEST Committee’s forthcoming report, the Member of the European Parliament, Pavel Poc, has also examined the implementation of the Plant Protection Regulation and the Parliament’s research services have already produced a study on this topic. We also have the Scientific Advice Mechanism’s (SAM) opinion on pesticides and the findings of the audits conducted by the Commission services in the Member States. Please be assured that all of these outputs will feed into the Commission’s analysis as we move ahead, and the PEST Committee report will provide valuable input for this exercise. While improvements within the current legal framework can be put in place swiftly, given the timing it will be for the next Commission to decide whether to propose changes to the legislation that ultimately would have to be adopted by the Parliament and Council. To conclude, I would like to stress that we all share the same goal: to maintain food safety, protect citizens’, animals’ and plants’ health, and to safeguard the environment. I want to thank you once again for the PEST Committee’s engagement and the valuable work undertaken by the PEST Committee and your House. In particular, I would to thank the Chair, Mr Andrieu, the Vice-Chairs, the co-rapporteurs, Mr Lins and Mr Staes, as well as the shadow rapporteurs. I look forward to the final adoption of the report on Wednesday and I assure you once again that all your precise, detailed and specific conclusions will be duly taken on board. We will continue to work tirelessly on increasing transparency, building trust and improving the sustainability of our food safety system. The Commission will assess carefully the final conclusions and recommendations in the context of its REFIT evaluation of the pesticides legislation.

name: Pilar Ayuso
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to congratulate the two rapporteurs on the great work they have done and you, Commissioner, for their involvement in these sensitive issues. In committee we have been working for months, listening to the experts and analysing the procedures for the authorisation of pesticides, both the Community and those of the Member States. I understand and share the objectives of transparency, of ensuring the level of protection of human health, increasing consumer confidence or reducing administrative burdens. However, the results of scientific opinions must be avoided from being questioned on the basis of ideological factors that condition the capacity for innovation and competitiveness. Due to the increasing mediatization of pesticide decision-making, this debate needs to be translated into the technical and scientific field. Decisions on pesticides should be made solely and exclusively by scientific criteria, without political and ideological interference. I would like to point out – as a person of contact with Parliament and EFSA – that this agency is independent and scientifically irreproachable, and that its work is in full application of the regulation in force. But it should not be forgotten that the procedure used by the Union to authorise plant protection products is one of the strictest in the world. What happens is that zero risk does not exist, and the use of these products also carries their risks, which can always be minimized; and I'm talking about dosages, the time of application or the application procedure. In conclusion, Commissioner, I think it would be very interesting for the Commission to prepare a communication with a view to talking and discussing the revision of legislation on plant protection products, in order to unify criteria and approve risk analysis procedures. I think this is very necessary.

name: Simona Bonafè
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with the work of the PEST Committee, the European Parliament has sought to highlight the major problems and respond to the increased criticisms involving the European plant protection products approval system. The report, which has already been voted on by a large majority in committee, has in fact sought to respond clearly to the millions of citizens who in recent years have raised the lack of transparency of the system, through the Stop Glyphosate initiative. In order to ensure the confidence of the whole system and to ensure that the protection of human health and the environment are the main objectives of EU legislation, the essential points we have fought for are, first of all, transparency, independence and the absence of conflicts of interest in EFSA's scientific panels. We have provided that each member will have to submit a declaration of interest. Secondly, the allocation of sufficient financial resources to the risk assessment authorities and, finally, appropriate expertise for the approval process. The final report covers a number of other aspects that have already been listed in previous interventions and which will have to be taken into account by the European Commission in its work on the revision of the regulation, such as the call for the creation of a post-marketing surveillance mechanism, capable of monitoring the real-life effects of the use of plant protection products. For the S&D Group, particular attention should be paid to risk assessment for the most vulnerable groups, and I am thinking in particular of the use of pesticides in the vicinity of schools, hospitals or public parks. It is also essential to invest in innovation in order to develop alternatives to plant protection products. In this context, specific regulation for pesticides with low biological risk will also be necessary, as Parliament has already requested. I hope that wednesday's plenary will be able to vote by a large majority on the final report, which is the result of constructive work, throughout the committee process, by the two rapporteurs, Mr Lins and Mr Staes, whom I thank, and that our contribution will be duly taken into account by the Commission.

name: Anthea McIntyre
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the EU’s approval process for plant protection products is one of the most stringent systems in the world, yet to read the PEST Committee’s report you really wouldn’t think so. Despite hearing from a range of experts and authorities, the report has been prepared in a very selective manner with many of these experts’ contributions being intentionally disregarded. The content doesn’t reflect the opinions we heard, instead it regurgitates the same beliefs and myths that we heard at the start of the process, even when these have been clearly and unanimously dispelled by experts: a supposed weakness of the rapporteur Member State system, allegations of plagiarism in assessment documentation, apparent failures of the zonal system... these have all been shown to be wide of the mark by invited experts. Yet many of these remain deliberately uncontested in this report in order to provide a platform for campaigning MEPs ahead of the elections in May. So the report is very disappointing and it reflects poorly on our institution, and that’s why we have presented plenary amendments to ensure that colleagues will be able to vote to support the real content of the committee hearings and not just the selected opinions of certain parliamentarians. We should support a fact-based and science-based approach to policy-making, and I hope that this Parliament will see the value of this approach and support the amendments presented by the ECR. Our current system isn’t perfect, it can be improved. We can act to improve transparency, which the Commission has already done in its proposal to revise the general food law. We can encourage innovation. We can support the development of new farming techniques which reduce pesticide use, and new active substances which will make older, more persistent, chemistry obsolete. The invited expert from Greenpeace said at the final hearing that it’s not flaws in the legislation that we need to address, but rather it is improvements to the implementation that are needed. So this report must strike a balance of opinion which reflects the objectives of the regulation and the breadth of the expert testimony, even where this is inconvenient for some political groups and campaigners.

name: Frédérique Ries
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, our PEST committee has carried out nine months of work, eight meetings, three missions abroad. It had a clear mandate: to scrutinize the malfunctions, or not, of our pesticide licensing system and, above all, to chart a course for the future. All of this came, it has been said, in the wake of the controversial renewal of glyphosate at the end of 2017. I would like to thank our two rapporteurs, Mr Staes and Mr Lins, for the excellent cooperation with them and also, I would like to say this, Eric Andrieu, an expert president, a demanding president and an empathetic president. So this is an ambitious report that we are debating tonight. The recommendations we make are strong and urgent. The report, which is widely supported in the PEST committee, takes the health of Europeans into account as a priority. We have scrupulously analysed the current shortcomings in the pesticide authorisation system and propose a list of recommendations immediately applicable to the Commission, Member States and EFSA.  Our first requirement is for the European Food Safety Agency: experts working with industry must be excluded from the pesticide authorisation process. Equally important for transparency is the creation of a public registry that records data and studies used by industry. We also call for Europe to increase EFSA's budget to strengthen its independence and effectiveness. I recall a figure that is often forgotten: today, EFSA's budget is four times lower than that of the European Medicines Agency. Food security deserves better than that. With regard to the coformulants, who, as we know, were at the heart of the dispute over glyphosate between the International Cancer Research Centre (IARC) and the European agencies, my question, Commissioner, is simple, in essence: when do you intend to apply the law and publish the first negative list, that is, of banning, of coformulants? However, we know today that the addition of adjuvants and synergists is at the heart of the toxicity of the products. Europe must also promote a zero pesticide policy in public spaces, nurseries, schools, hospitals, playgrounds and, finally, extend the ban to other bee-killing neonicotinoids than those already banned. I'm thinking here of thiaclopride.  In conclusion, Europe has no choice - I conclude, Mr President, I assure you - it must follow the recommendations of the PEST committee. Protecting our environment is a citizen's priority. It must be at the heart of our decisions.

name: Thomas Waitz
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the It is often argued that 10 to 15 percent crop increases or higher tonnage during harvesting are used for some dangerous pesticides. But at what cost do we use the pesticides here, when we have dead soils, when we then have a loss in biodiversity, when we then have explosive problems in the health system? All of this, too, ultimately demands economic costs, and it is a high price to pay. There is no doubt that some pesticides or many pesticides pose unacceptable risks, cause damage to the environment, to the citizens, but also to the farmers who use these pesticides. In order to increase the control and scrutiny of pesticides in the authorisation procedure with transparency and with the control of the corporations and in the future, taking greater account of health and environmental aspects, I would ask you to vote in favour of this report. Mrs McIntyre, you say that this report reflects the opinion of a single group, an ideological opinion. I think you mean us Greens. What do you think: how does a compromise with the European People's Party, social democracy, the GUE, the liberals come about? It is actually everyone in this House who is in favour, but you, Mrs McIntyre, who have tabled over a hundred amendments which seek to disscutey this report and do the industry a favour. I do not think that is what the citizens expect of us.

name: Anja Hazekamp
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Europe's approval of Monsanto's glyphosate is and remains a major scandal. It is now more than a year since Monsanto, the German Federal Institute for Risk Assessment, the food authority EFSA and the European Commission together pushed this approval through to the EU Member States.  This decision was taken on the basis of dubious, manipulated and industry-supplied studies. Europe is taking unacceptable risks to the health of more than 500 million citizens and animal health. Europe is allowing more and more of this poison to be pumped into our environment, our waters, our food and our bodies. In response to the glyphosate scandal, the European Parliament set up this special committee of inquiry into the authorisation procedure for pesticides. The recommendations of this special committee on pesticide authorisation are promising. Europe must become more transparent and, independently of industry, determine whether agricultural poison is safe for use. Less poison should be used in its entirety. The use of agricultural poison in public places should be prohibited. And animals should no longer be abused to demonstrate the so-called safety of poison. As the rapporteur has just pointed out, the Union Special Commission authorisation procedure for pesticides wants animal test-free testing methods.  All good recommendations that the Party for Animals wholeheartedly endorses. I therefore assume that these recommendations are embraced by the European Commission, but also by the European Council, and that they are included in general food legislation.  All that remains is the cleaning up of remnants of the past. Glyphosate should be directly off the market, because there is no basis for the issued approval. That is also what one million citizens have asked of us. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Mireille D’Ornano
text: on behalf of the EFDD group. Mr President, Co-ministers, Commissioner, in March 2017, the US federal court declassified more than 250 pages of internal documents from Monsanto. Their contents proved that the agrochemical firm was seriously concerned, 20 years ago, about the mutagen risk of glyphosate, the most widely used plant protection molecule in the world. However, on the eve of these revelations, the European Chemicals Agency published a report that considered glyphosate to be neither carcinogenic nor mutagenic. Unlucky: the "Monsanto papers" scandal had just erupted and was about to have global repercussions. At the end of 2017, the European Commission declared the European Citizens' Initiative entitled 'Baning glyphosate and protecting the population and the environment from toxic pesticides' eligible. It was signed by more than a million citizens. Shortly thereafter, the European Parliament established a special committee on pesticides. Co-ordinator for my group, I attended all the hearings organized in the presence of the actors involved in the authorisation procedure. I was, I must say, particularly surprised by the ambiguity, even the lies assailed in some pseudo-scientific responses of pesticide advocates and agrochemical lobbies - all this was edifying. In any event, 1,141 amendments were tabled in committee, probably because of a draft report that did not go far enough and prompted totally antagonistic positions. Today, in plenary, 152 amendments are now tabled, the vast majority of which are in favour of pesticides. The majority of these amendments propose to remove the troublesome passages in the text and consist in a way of rewriting them. For my part, I have tabled only one amendment, which seems to me to be of extreme urgency and which deals with a subject of difficult questionable gravity: it is a question of amending the regulation to ensure the effective protection of vulnerable groups. The aim is to put an end, without delay or derogation, to the application of pesticides over long distances near homes, schools, nurseries, playgrounds, hospitals, maternity wards or health care facilities. It should be noted that I have garnered the support of most political groups to co-sign this amendment, proof of its consensual and balanced nature. If the pro-pesticide amendments were to be adopted and thus to distort a text that was already very timid and very disappointing as to what to do, it will be clear that this is yet another victory for the lobbies. On the other hand, Members can emerge from this vote by adopting amendments that are geared towards the protection of vulnerable people and, more generally, public health.

name: Philippe Loiseau
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, this PEST committee was set up as a result of the Monsanto papers. The aim was therefore neither to try pesticides nor to exempt them from any harm, it was in fact to identify loopholes and collusions in the European process, and of course to remedy them. As is often the case here, the mountain has given birth to a mouse. As is often the case, the desire for consensus has replaced political firmness and listening to peoples. A prominent member of this assembly, Bruno Gollnisch, said about this search for consensus at the expense of substance, I quote: "This is the house of gifts. Everyone and especially his brother must be pleased, except of course when his brother is part of the Europe of Nations and Freedoms group." The result is logically a catch-all text, where the only ideas that emerge actually aggravate the situation. My proposals, in line with the desire of the peoples, who demand more national sovereignty, are obviously victims of a political sectarianism, which is fortunately dying.  In substance, the goodwill of the two co-owners was drowned out by the blindness of the smug Europeanists. A great French writer, Bossuet, said: "God laughs at men who deplore the effects of which they cherish the causes." This maxim seems to have been written for the European Union, for its supporters, and I think even for this committee on pesticides. Most of my colleagues agreed on one point: EFSA was the problem, through its obscure governance, its expensive financial management and its proximity to the big industry. Unfortunately, these same purveyors of an all-powerful agency finally want to strengthen its means, its power and its influence. In other words, when the European Union creates problems, more European Union is needed to solve them. The Eurosceptic wave in Italy, Austria or Poland, the yellow vests in France, Brexit: all these upheavals are very clear. People don't want to see their states die. They do not want more Europe. They refuse standards unrelated to their needs.  Our amendments were therefore based on simple ideas about the process of authorising substances. It must go back to the States as a whole, it must take into account the experience, of course, of farmers in a new pesticido-vigilance system, it must also be more transparent, it must finally be more consistent with the european Union's trade policy. That is, if a substance is banned in Europe, of course it must also be banned from importing products containing that substance.  Finally, EFSA must take responsibility for its actions. The joke, I think, lasted long enough. I therefore call for the resignation of the leaders of this agency, as the basic premise of a total overhaul of the product authorisation system, an overhaul that our group has proposed through precise and concise amendments, quite the opposite, in fact, of the texts usually coming out of this institution.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE).
text: – Mr President-in-Office, Honourable Commissioner, colleagues and colleagues, co-rapporteurs Lins and Staes, I would like to thank Commissioner Andriukaitis for his very engaged work.  With the final report of the Committee on Pesticide Registration, we want to strengthen our attitude towards food quality and restore citizens' trust in European institutions. It is about time that pesticides stopped poisoning our fields and meadows, and it is also time for pesticides to stop poisoning our political debates. Health first! The time before each election is particularly receptive to quick solutions, which prefer to refer to simple slogans and generalisations rather than facts, and the upcoming European elections are no exception. I therefore welcome the PEST report, which calls for a systematic review of all studies on the impact of glyphosate on human health and the environment, which will form the basis for our follow-up.  However, I think that much more needs to be done to restore people's trust in European institutions. Different agencies have given us different results in terms of the carcinogenicity of glyphosate and other pesticides. There are still concerns, and time is running out of facts.  The use of chemical pesticides in the preparation, in food production, harms both air, water and soil, as well as biodiversity and human health. It is no longer just a question of restoreing public trust, it is increasingly about respecting the knowledge of science and insisting that, even as politicians, we no longer agree to compromise at the expense of health.  As chair of the Group of Members on Combating Cancer, I can say that, as a society, we are understandably busy finding medicines and methods of treatment in the fight against this increasingly common disease, and we are not doing enough to address the causes of it. Cancer is not just a private matter for doctors and patients, cancer is a political and social problem. If we are to achieve positive changes in health, we need to change our European development paradigm, including agricultural policy.  Alternatives to chemical pesticides already exist, but we lack the will to change the legislative framework. The PEST report is a step in the right direction, which I welcome.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D).
text: – Thank you, Mr President, and I also thank the rapporteurs and all those who have been involved in our almost year's work. My report on the implementation of the European Regulation on plant protection products, which was kindly mentioned by the Commissioner and which was adopted by this Parliament by a majority last year, has made it quite clear that there are cracks in our system of authorising, which ultimately result in a lack of protection of public health and the environment. Today, therefore, thanks to the work of the Special Committee on the table, we have really excellent comprehensive recommendations on how to substantially improve this European authorisation system for authorising pesticides and restore citizens' confidence in our decision-making. I am therefore quite shocked that my colleagues in the ECR Group are trying to completely devalue this joint work with plenary amendments. Their proposals erase entire passages aimed at ensuring better protection of particularly vulnerable groups, such as children, pregnant women, seeking, among other things, to block proposals to assess developmental neurotoxicity, the long-term effect of pesticides, exposure to sub-limit amounts of several pesticides at once or a combination of these substances. After all, the aim is food safety and health and environmental protection, and I absolutely do not understand why the Conservatives want to deny this information to both decision-making decision-making and the citizens themselves. That's absurd.  I would like to point out here, Mr President, that any European legislation is to be based on the principle of precautionary principle, which we must apply unconditionally whenever there is scientific uncertainty about the risks to human health, animals and the impact on the environment. After all, the substance of the proposed measures is intended to help eliminate this scientific uncertainty, but also, of course, to improve farmers' access to safer alternatives to chemical pesticides and to increase the transparency of the entire approval system, which is in everyone's interest. I believe that the vote on this report is one of those that the European public will be watching and will remember in some 130 days.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It is about a year since the use of glyphosate was still permitted. This has put not only our food chain, but also the livelihoods of farmers throughout Europe and, not least, our health, at risk. I can only partially agree with the report by the PEST Committee, because it destroys the work that the Commission has already done and gets more input from lobby groups than from the scientific side. The proposal to place more responsibility in EFSA's hands sounds like a good idea – but only if the Agency has sufficient resources to do so. But we also leave responsibility to the countries, to the local farmers. The local farmer knows best how to produce sustainable food. Let us ask science and fewer large corporations how we want to shape an ecological and healthy future. I want us in Europe to have healthy agriculture in the future, not an agricultural industry.

name: Jan Huitema (ALDE).
text: Mr President, this is yet another debate we have about plant protection products and I know that there will be a few more before the elections. What I always worry about is that this always calls science into question. I think it is important to say once again that we have the strictest and safest admission procedure in the whole world in the European Union. Substances such as alcohol, caffeine and even vitamin D should not be allowed in plant protection products. I understand the emotion. Of course, food safety and public health must always be secure. But what I am afraid of – besides that we are always questioning science – is that the appreciation for the farmer is also coming under increasing pressure. Whichever agricultural system you use, in the production of food you intervene in nature and you have an environmental impact.  What we forget is that farmers have already minimized their environmental impact in recent decades and are keen to invest to further reduce the environmental impact. And if you're producing food, you need farmland. You get that from nature. To protect your crops, you still have certain resources. If you don't, you lose your harvest, you have food waste and you need more land for your agricultural production.  What I want to do here, and what I want to do, is to give farmers adequate tools to protect those crops properly. This can be done by technological solutions such as precision agriculture, but also by ecological solutions. Use the power of nature through breeding, more attention to the soil and low-risk resources.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE).
text: Commissioner, rapporteurs, this glyphosate scandal has shown the manipulation of science of which we are all victims. It showed how big companies kidnapped science and hijacked it for their own benefit - we saw it in the case of the "Monsanto papers". The evidence was so overwhelming and glaring that we succeeded, first to three Members, and then with the commitment of the Green and Socialist groups, to obtain a special committee on the procedure for authorising pesticides in the European Union. Thanks to this committee, we have been able to discover in detail the flaws in the European authorisation system. A system of prodigious complexity, which always manages to allow the authorization of pesticides on the market. It is still incredible to know that it is the industrialist who chooses the rapporteur Member State responsible for studying his application, who eliminates studies whose results displease him to keep only his own, who decides not to communicate by playing on the secrecy of business - remember, Commissioner, we did not have the authorisation to see the studies that the industrialists had. And these same industrialists are the authors of the evaluations made, in the form of anonymous copy and paste, from the studies they themselves have carried out. It is also incredible that substances can be allowed in the absence of the expected regulatory studies and benefit from temporary exemptions or authorizations that are constantly being extended. It is still incredible that pesticide products in third countries are not as evaluated or tested as substances authorised at European level.  It is very important that all colleagues vote on this report. The European elections will take place in May, which is why it is very important that we all stand together for the health of European citizens. We need to show that it is up to politicians to decide the legislation and that it is not up to multinationals to decide which products are going to be evaluated. The future of Europe is at stake.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I was at the beginning when the mandate for this committee was written. That is why I remember well what arguments in the negotiations fell from the mouths of mainly right-wing factions. I remember being angry several times that if the mandate were to look the way they wanted, there was no point in setting up a committee at all. Some of the worst measures to ensure that nothing is investigated have been prevented, unfortunately not the rest. The result of the work looks like it, too.  On the one hand, we have a number of positive things, such as addressing the issue of plagiarism, the transparency of studies, conflicts of interest or proposals to improve the evaluation of products. However, then there are questions about glyphosate or the sustainable use of pesticides, which have simply been put down. Overall, the negotiations in the committee did not go very well, with the constant rejection of the experts proposed by the opposition being just one of the marginals.  I would like to appeal to you not to weaken such a weak report even further in the plenary vote. If that happens, the result of the annual work will be no more than the start of a campaign for some of us.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, at last this global battle, which I believe to be global, against pesticides and pesticides, against chemical-based agriculture, is yielding its first results, including at the level of the European institutions, this is important, after the important results it has already achieved on citizens, by citizens, in terms of increasing awareness of the risks that these substances bring to health. The report that we voted on in the PEST Committee is a good one, but we believe that it needs to be improved and that it does not yet correspond to the need for transparency and health that comes precisely from the citizens. That is why we have tabled amendments for an immediate stop to the preventive use of pesticides, for example. This type of practice cannot be considered something that goes in the direction of the elimination of chemistry and if we want chemistry-free agriculture this goes in the completely opposite direction. Amendments to eliminate substances which have an established endocrine interference action. Incredibly, in the European Union, these substances were first approved by the Eu ropean Union itself and then authorised by the States. Amendments to eliminate those substances which have certainly been classified as neurotoxic and for which, unfortunately, the European Union has renewed its authorisation, as in the case of the infamous chlorpyrifos, which is used, as you know, on our bananas. The next step, as has already been said, is to ban imports. There is no point in having all these battles here in Europe, over our legislation, when we then unhinderedly allow glyphosate-treated substances to be imported, for example, from abroad. The only possibility for the plant protection industry, from our point of view, must remain to continue to use its products unhindered only if they are unaware of people's knowledge and for this reason it is our first objective, here, is an objective of transparency, in order to make citizens informed and aware, and for this I thank all those Members who , courageously and obstinacy, have waged this battle to this point, in the interests of the citizens of Europe.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – Mr President, and at the outset of the sincere congratulations of the honourable rapporteurs, Mr Lins and Mr Staes, who have produced a balanced report, but have had to answer to the difficult issue, the topic of pesticide use, also authorised around glyphosate.  We are talking about health, that the topic is important, it is supported by people signing a petition, and we know that when we take care of our health, we intervene in medicines. The less they need to be used, the more we see them, and the same is also the case in agriculture, where it is necessary to cut down on pesticides for plant protection. All technologies are smaller in both conventional, integrated agriculture and organic farming, where this use is small, smaller but exists.  What matters is what has been said, that we are talking about evolution, that we are not talking about revolution. The agricultural sector is changing, and I know exactly what farmers have to do, how this has changed over the last 30 years and how it goes towards greener use of pesticides, less pesticide use, greater transparency.  These rules, where science is respected, transparency and support for innovation, are the right orientations. In the latter case, I think it is very important to ensure, on the one hand, that efse has sufficient capacity to lead and successfully control these processes, and, on the other hand, to innovate for new technologies, including robotics, with targeted agriculture and by moving towards greener European agriculture, in which a new agricultural policy is also heading in the direction. I will certainly support the report.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D).
text: Madam President, protecting the health of 500 million Europeans, preserving the richness of our biodiversity, is our responsibility. It is for this reason that the report we co-authored calls for more transparency in the work of our experts, more independence from our agencies and strict application of the precautionary principle. These are the three areas that structure the quality of this report. I would like here, as chairman of this committee, to congratulate and thank, first, the two co-ministers, Norbert Lins and Bart Staes, who have done an excellent job from my point of view, but, beyond that, also thank and congratulate all the members who have worked during the nine months of this committee. Madam President, as you have seen, not all have worked with the same force, and some have still remained certain about their early certainties. Ms. McIntyre is in that category. I think that this commission could have lasted an entire mandate, nothing would have changed to its certainties of departure and that is a shame. Democracy does not grow. The recommendations reflect nine months of work, but also the growing and legitimate demands of our citizens in terms of transparency and human health. Today, some industrialists are debauchery of former MPs to buy a new virginity. We must tell them forcefully that they are not above the law, and we demand that manufacturers such as Bayer and Monsanto make public all their scientific studies when applying for marketing authorization.  From this point of view, Commissioner, the proposals you have made to us to improve the procedure for authorising pesticides by EFSA, voted by our Parliament on 11 December, are a step in the right direction, and I would like to thank Pavel Poc for his excellent work.  We need to go further. We call on the Commission to propose communication as soon as possible, followed by an overhaul of EU legislation on the authorisation of pharmaceuticals. It is about the health of Europeans, the future is about the clarity and the relevance of the work we are doing here in the European Parliament and that you are leading in the European Commission.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: Mr President, when the debate on glyphosate erupted three years ago, I repeatedly insisted on the importance of greater transparency and independent investigation.  This is also the main conclusion of the Union Special Commission authorisation procedure for pesticides, and my delegation fully supports those conclusions. The approval of plant protection products must be carried out on the basis of and with respect for independent and objective science and in accordance with a transparent, objective and high-performing procedure. We do indeed have one of the strictest systems in the world, but improvements are possible and necessary to ensure citizens' confidence in scientifically based policies and to ensure the protection of public health and the environment.  Two critical reservations to close. The key question of whether or not glyphosate is carcinogenic can only be answered by additional research, not by a political committee. Finally, I hope that this report can stimulate a broader debate on more sustainable agriculture.  (The speaker responds to a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: 'blue card' question. Mr Demesmaeker, I have just heard you say that you fully support the committee's recommendations. In the European Parliament, you are part of the same group as Mrs McIntyre. Can you explain why you are in for the conclusions of this commission and share its conclusions, knowing that Ms. McIntyre is against it? Can you clarify that?

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: "blue card" answer. – The answer is very simple: I am speaking and voting here on behalf of my delegation, which is a four-member N-VA delegation. And I run my party's program.

name: Martin Häusling (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the We must restore confidence among the citizens, because we have lost a great deal of confidence in the processes of the European Union in the authorisation process for glyphosate. In fact, there is the impression outside that the interests of chemistry play a greater role than the interests of the environment and health. We urgently need to correct this. There is a lot wrong with the approval processes. The mere fact that we have to rely on chemistry studies on whether or not certain pesticides are harmful to health cannot remain the case. We need more independent research, that is quite clear. We need full transparency. And we can really apply this to the new food law. There is the exciting question to the Conservative side of whether it agrees with what the Commission has presented, or whether some of them are already buckling at that point. That is why this is the key point: full transparency. But we must also actually promote the alternatives to this type of chemical agriculture. It cannot continue in such a way that the use of chemistry is self-evident. This can only be the absolute exception.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, this report is important that no one will be able to say''I did not know'. Everyone now knows that you bear responsibility for one of the most serious health scandals in Europe, that of glyphosate, because, knowingly, it has been decided to continue poisoning people. Yes, the Commission failed to protect the health of its citizens and preferred to protect the lobbies of multinationals such as Monsanto. I say this with seriousness: the current procedures for putting pesticides on the market are not Europe that protects, it is Europe that pollutes, and it is Europe that kills the living.  I therefore call on you, once again, to rescind the marketing authorization for the contested pesticides, starting with glyphosate and bee-killing pesticides.

name: Esther Herranz García (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we are discussing measures to ensure the health of citizens, and that health is ensured by controlling the environment and food.  It is important that we ensure that plant protection products are used correctly and that their effect is the one we are looking for, the one desired for health and for the environment. It is also necessary to help to help to continue producing fruits and vegetables in the European Union. So far I think we can all agree, but banning by banning is neither sensible nor logical.  Decisions have to be made based on scientific criteria. Our institutions, with EFSA at the forefront, are in a position to provide information, to provide transparency, security and certainty to European citizens.  Let us therefore allow scientists to work and, from politics, let us ensure that there are the means for them to continue working without politicizing science, because we will do citizens bad favor if instead of scientific certainties, we offer them ideological messages and misrepresented opinions, as in the case of glyphosate.  That is what I would like to say today, in addition to thanking you for your work, especially my colleague Mr Lins, who I know has done a very thorough job and a great effort with this document.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, in view of the various hearings that took place at the PEST committee meetings, it is a fact that the European procedure for authorising pesticides needs to be improved.  I have been fighting for a long time and for many months to shed light on the shortcomings in this area, and I am pleased that the original text of the two co-speakers, who have also worked very well and which I congratulate, has been further improved on various points. I quote six quickly. One, a better application of the precautionary principle. Two, a strengthening of independence throughout the authorization process. Three, the need for the Commission and member states to allocate sufficient resources to strengthen independence. Four, the need to find alternative products by fostering innovation. Five, the establishment of a post-marketing monitoring mechanism and, six, the addition of criteria for independence and transparency and the absence of a conflict of interest in the definition of the rapporteur Member State.  I therefore welcome the conclusions of this special committee and hope that they will be fully translated into the vote.

name: James Nicholson (ECR).
text: – Madam President, can I say at the beginning, maybe for Mr Tarabella, that I’ll be supporting Ms McIntyre’s view on this particular issue and maybe that will allay his fears. My view is very simple. For producers, herbicides like glyphosate are not a luxury, they are a necessity. Not only is responsible use of herbicides vital in the production of food, it is also beneficial in reducing greenhouse gas emissions and promoting sustainable farming. The EU rightly champions high standards in food production and the importance of protecting public health, and I agree with all of that, food safety and the environment. The best way to do this is by formulating a policy based on scientific evidence. I agree with you, Commissioner: how do you guarantee some of this? But somewhere along the line you have to trust somebody, and if you’ve got to trust somebody, you’ve got to trust those who are actually in charge of science. Now I am nor saying this is totally secure 100%, because there is no such thing as 100% security, but trust somebody. You’ve got to do it, and there has to be a scientific point of view.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I welcome the work of the rapporteurs who, on such a sensitive subject, have given common sense the scientific evidence to the detriment of a negative campaign based on false data, which many are trying to pass on to take electoral advantage. In the EPP we do not embark on these populist drifts, always being at the side of our constituents in defending their rights, the best information available and in the search for the best solutions. This is also the case with regard to agriculture, which many want to pass on as the sector responsible for a less correct use of these products.  This is totally false. Not only are pesticides used by a wide spectrum of society and the most varied professions, but farmers are the main ones interested in responsible use of them. I would remind you that, according to the most recent study on the presence of pesticide residues in the agri-food sector, it showed that 97.2% of samples in Europe were within the legal limits of EU law, which shows an extremely strict and safest food production system in the world. That is why European citizens can rely on their institutions as well as supervisory bodies. This is also what I was able to shape in the document for which I was responsible in the Committee on Agriculture.  There is obviously always room to improve and that is why I welcome the increase in funding, both for the European Food Safety Agency and for the authorities of the Member States, so that these entities can do their work even better. That is what we are here for, that we work to develop the confidence of Europeans in our Europe.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate all the participants in the Special Committee on the Procedure for the Authorisation of the Union for Pesticides and especially the rapporteurs, because I believe that, finally, the resolution which was adopted in the committee, and which we are debating today, is a good proposal. I would like to make clear my support for any initiative involving strengthening transparency, more information to consumers, increasing their confidence and reducing administrative burdens, as well as ensuring quality in scientific opinions. Of course, supporting these initiatives, within the framework of the European Union's pesticide authorisation procedure, has been all the work that has been done. However, in view of the increasing mediatisation of decision-making regarding the use of these products, sometimes absolutely outside of scientific knowledge, I believe, ladies and gentlemen, that we should try to bring the debate back to the technical and scientific field of the institutions. Still, I think it's a good agreement that deserves everyone's approval when the vote occurs.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Speaking in this debate on the own-initiative report on the EU authorisation procedure for pesticides, it should be noted that the European Commission's agreement to use glyphosate in the Union, expressed in December 2017 for the next five years, i.e. until 2022, has caused great public dissatisfaction and has consequently resulted in the establishment of a special PEST committee by Parliament. The negative public sentiment in this case stems primarily from a court ruling in the United States in August 2018 that monsanto glyphosate caused lymphoma in an American gardener and ordered him to pay nearly $300 million.  The SPECIAL PEST Committee set up by Parliament in its report has proposed, inter alia, greater transparency in pesticide research and avoidance of conflicts of interest in research into pesticides, as well as a ban on the use of plant protection products in public places. Unfortunately, this report does not represent a breakthrough on the use of pesticides in agriculture.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, glyphosate or not glyphosate? That was the question. But what our citizens expect is simple: ensuring their food security and transparency in decision-making. The answer is just as simple: science. We have heard from experts, we have met many professionals in the field and, more than ever, I am convinced that science must be the indisputable basis of our decisions. This is what I have been advocating for more than three years in this Chamber, and I welcome the fact that the report has reached the same conclusions. We need to work towards a greater understanding of procedures by citizens. We must restore confidence in national and European agencies, but also in our institutions. We have one of the most demanding and protective systems in the world in Europe, let us not forget. In my view, a high level of security requirements is a necessary but not sufficient condition. The farmer I am, who has been campaigning for more than ten years for the alternative to plant protection products and the use of plant protection products, can attest to this. Be demanding, yes, but while guaranteeing our food sovereignty. We must give ourselves the means of our ambitions. We need to support research and innovation. Let's not be naïve, if we don't allow companies to do research, innovation will come from their competitors. We must also support professionals and the agricultural sectors to move towards ever more environmentally friendly practices. Let us not oppose agriculture and the environment: all agriculture has its place and meets different expectations. Above all, we must support farmers in the face of global competition: let us not import agriculture that we do not want, otherwise we will shoot ourselves in the foot, both in terms of health, the environment and the economy. I believe that the report we have on the table meets these objectives and I would like to commend the work of our rapporteurs. Even if not everything is perfect, since some of our proposals have not been fully taken up, the main thing is there. I also hope that we will have a quick response from the Commission, as my colleague Pilar Ayuso pointed out, at the end of what I hope will be a massive vote.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D).
text: Madam President! The Glyphosate debate has been very fraught in the past year, and rightly so. We have discussed whether the substance has been dangerous, whether we have used it in the right way. That is why it was very good that we in the European Parliament chose to set up a committee to look at whether we had done the right thing, whether we could find another and better way of authorizing new pesticides. After most of a year of work, the committee has come up with a large number of very good and very necessary conclusions. I cannot highlight all of them here - I do not have time for this - but I would like to emphasise three pieces: one is that we have chosen to emphasise the need for much more transparency in the approval procedure. We simply need to know where a report comes from, what it is for some researchers who have been in charge of it and how have they been paid. Secondly, we need greater independence in eu bodies: ECHA simply needs more money so that they can do more independent studies. Finally, we must base everything on the precautionary principle. I support the conclusions and hope that they will be adopted so that we can make them law in the European Union in the future.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, tá áthas orm labhairt ar an ábhar tábhachtach seo, agus is maith an rud é go bhfuil díospóireacht ar siúl faoi sa Pharlaimint um thráthnóna. Firstly, allow me to state that I welcome the work of this committee and the opportunity for Parliament to scrutinise this issue. As the Commissioner pointed out earlier, it is an issue that has received much attention and about which we have all received many questions and concerns from constituents.  I come from Ireland south, a rather rural and agricultural constituency. Every day I speak to farmers about their work and pesticides, especially glyphosate, has been at the forefront of their concerns. Farmers are understanding of the problem but are frustrated at the same time because of lack of alternatives.  Let me be clear: it is crucial to safeguard the value and authority of the scientific institutions. We cannot allow science to be guided by politics. Our citizens depend on stable, legal and safe rules and frameworks. We must ensure that there is trust in the system, as Mr Nicholson pointed out, otherwise we might as well have no approval process in place, as there would be no trust in it. The EU approval system is one of the safest in the world. However, there are ways to improve it.
