We must ensure that we safeguard the highest standards for the health of our EU citizens, the environment, but also ensure the survival of EU farms. This is the balance that can and must be found.  It is vital that we consider the reliance our farmers have on certain products. In Ireland, for example, the practice of desiccation, i.e. the application of a herbicide to a crop shortly before harvest, is vital to some of our famers, particularly our potato farmers. We in Ireland have a temperate oceanic climate. We do not have the weather conditions for drying crops in the sun, and therefore desiccation is necessary. Alternatives need to be found to put new and better equipped products on the markets, and any restrictions on this in the years ahead, in the absence of viable alternatives, would be detrimental to the tillage sector. Tá jab maith déanta ag an Rapóirtéir agus a chomhghleacaithe.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, respect for the European precautionary principle is essential to ensure food safety. In recent years, however, the credibility of our authorisation system for plant protection products has been greatly undermined by the opacity of the procedure for renewing the authorisation of glyphosate, which is all the more serious because doubts about the danger of glyphosate have grown and are also confirmed by court rulings recogniseing between the professional use of glyphosate and the onset of cancer. Concerns about transparency and conflicts of interest highlight the need to improve the authorisation regulation for its application. The report by the PEST Special Committee highlights the need to focus on citizens' health, the environment and food safety, ensuring that EFSA has adequate financial resources, independence from lobbies, no conflicts of interest and adequate expertise in the approval processes. However, we must remedy the mistakes of the past by directing agriculture towards sustainable practices.

name: Julie Girling (PPE).
text: – Madam President, neither I nor my political group were in favour of setting up the special committee in the first place. I didn’t think there was any need for such an instrument to address the Citizens’ Initiative on glyphosate, a subject which is aired with monotonous regularity in this Chamber, and we’ve talked about it probably more than any other subject when it comes to chemicals for agriculture.  Undoubtedly it’s very important, I absolutely agree, and I’ve certainly never sought to diminish the importance of making sure that we have a good system, but it is fairly universally acknowledged that the EU system is pretty much the best that there is. And indeed – not wishing to sit on our laurels – we know that the Commission, and our Commissioner, put forward under the general food law proposals, some proposals which very much address the issues that so many of the Members of this House have spoken of this afternoon.  My fundamental problem with this report is that it has taken a huge amount of effort and energy – and I commend our rapporteurs for the work that they’ve put in – but in doing so, what actually do we gain? Running parallel, we have a legislative report on general food law which pretty much looks at almost all of the issues which are raised here – certainly all of those which fall within the sensible remit of this Parliament. That is not to say that we didn’t get an awful lot of amendments that were a little bit, how shall I put it, ‘idealistic’, but most of those have been subsumed into the sorts of compromises that we are so very good at here, but which actually in the end, don’t lead us any further forward. So I shall not be voting for this report. I think it should go forward as a monument of how we are very, very good at establishing ways to waste our time and I look forward to dealing with the general food law, which is a far more important piece of legislation.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I welcome the reference in the report to the need to strengthen research and innovation in the area of crop protection. This should be our main path: to seek new technical solutions and methodologies that will reduce, in a sustained way, the use of plant protection products and, when their use is necessary, how to do so in the most efficient and targeted way, always having as indisputable priorities the precautionary principle and the protection of human, animal and environmental health. We must also ensure that farmers have at their disposal the tools necessary for adequate protection of their crops to ensure the viability of their farms. As such, the system for authorising these products in the European Union, always based on the strictest scientific criteria, should be an agile system capable of presenting solutions for the great diversity of European agricultural production, particularly in more challenging situations such as those encountered in the outermost regions.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, ensuring a high level of protection of human and animal health is a key objective of the European Union. This means taking measures and, above all, applying the precautionary principle, which, as you know, is a fundamental principle of the European Union and is provided for in Article 191 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. Furthermore, there must be transparency in the adoption of measures, the study carried out by an independent authority, and decisions which essentially serve the chemical industry must not be taken. Besides, we had the glyphosate scandal. We have a decision by the citizens of the European Union, who have taken a European initiative. However, Commissioner, Mr Andriukaitis, I would like to raise a serious issue: agricultural products are being imported from Turkey. These products are unfortunately grown with pesticides which are prohibited. So what about imports of Turkish agricultural products grown in Turkey with pesticides that are banned and nevertheless imported into the European Union, imported into Greece and dangerous to the health of citizens? I want to take action on this issue.

name: Florent Marcellesi (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, we can now say this more clearly: the glyphosate authorisation did not have the guarantees it owed. A large majority of this House recognizes this in the special commission set up at the initiative of the Verts/ALE Group.  The process of authorisation of pesticides in the European Union is too vulnerable to conflicts of interest. European agencies should, from now on, independently, objectively and transparently assess the effects of pesticides on our health and the environment, starting, of course, with glyphosate, potentially carcinogenic according to the World Health Organization.  From this House we ask for assessments — at last – based on scientific data and not on accounting data from multinationals such as Monsanto.  And this, let us not deceive ourselves, is thanks to the movement's struggle for healthy and sustainable agriculture and food. We will continue to work for a Europe that always puts our health and the environment ahead of us.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the establishment of this special committee on pesticide authorisation procedures has resulted from public suspicion about the accuracy and transparency of these procedures. This suspicion did not fall from the sky. The promiscuity that exists between the European Commission, its agencies and the interests of the industry dominated by transnational colossi in the case of Chemistry and Pharmaceuticals is well known.  The principles of prevention and precaution are not always taken into account in authorisation procedures. It is public health and the preservation of the environment that must prevail over the interests of industry, its expectations of profit and not the other way around. Risk analyses cannot serve as a justification for turning this basic principle upside down. This applies both to the necessary authorisation to monitor the impact of what already exists on the market, as well as for the management of innovation processes and for the large-scale application of new products.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, therefore, protecting the health of our citizens is one of the most important of our tasks, and that is why this report is all the more important because it calls for an independent, objective and transparent assessment of pesticides and, of course, its effects.  Let us just remember this scandal, this glyphosate saga, which has sparked a huge debate in the process of renewing the authorisation about whether glyphosate is carcinogenic or not. And the studies that emerged at the time really cast doubt. Especially since these studies also contained the fingerprints of certain plant protection industries, i.g. those that produce these glyphosates.  And that is why we need to ensure independent, objective assessments, and above all, to ensure public access to all available industry studies, because in the doubt that studies are independent, public scrutiny will always be necessary, because only in this way can trust be provided.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D).
text: Madam President, I have heard some colleagues say that the European food safety system is effective and that we should trust the health authorities. But, in the name of the precautionary principle, we should make sure that we do not have all the inconveniences we know. I take the example of chlordecon in the French West Indies. You know for a fact all the harm that this does to people. Prostate cancer has increased dramatically. We can see that we are in a situation where almost 80% of the population is affected.  We say yes to greater transparency, but in the name of the precautionary principle, we say that everything must be done to ensure that our populations are better protected. My colleague Eric Andrieu and I have asked to lower the limits - MRSAs - for meat products. So far, we have no answer.  We expect you to do everything necessary to ensure that we have a better guarantee of the health of our people.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I have listened very carefully to the interventions of the Honourable Members and I am grateful for them. Allow me to react to some of them. Ms Ries raised the question of co-formulants. We are working on both the list and on the criteria. As of December, we discussed with Member States the first list of unacceptable co-formulants, including those already identified by the Member States, and discussions are ongoing. Speaking about products coming from third countries and maximum residual levels that MEP Marias just raised, in principle the same maximum residual levels apply for imported and domestically produced food and feed commodities – absolutely, crystal clear. Where no maximum residual level exists for a commodity not produced in the EU or because a substance is not approved, so-called import tolerance can be requested for commodities produced in the third country. However, such import tolerances can only be granted if confirmed by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), following a thorough scientific evaluation that the risk to consumers can be excluded and therefore the high level of protection in the EU is fully ensured. Please convey this message to all the people who ask about the possibility of regulating issues related to goods coming from third countries. Of course, generally, some blame me because I am poisoning people. It is strange for me, a little bit. My father taught me the first rule: son, don’t lie to people. My message is, with elections coming up, don’t lie. This is a very good message – a simple message. The second simple message is please trust in science. If you trust in science then the situation will be more or less OK. I think it is a good opportunity now to listen to your conclusions and recommendations. We will give very careful consideration to your final document and we can take it into account in our REFIT evaluation that I will present to you in the first half of this year. I strongly believe that we share the same goal – to maintain food safety, protect citizens and animal and plant health, and safeguard the environment. I think we are generally doing a good job.

name: Norbert Lins
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has We have seen – the emotional debate has shown it – that we have very different views on this issue. Nevertheless, I believe that this is a success, that we have managed to draw up a consensus report across party lines and also across our ideologies. In doing so, we are strengthening the science-based approach that we so desperately need in this authorisation procedure. I appeal again: emotions really have nothing to do with this. I am addressing my colleagues – some of whom are no longer there – for example Mr Waitz, who generally denigrates pesticides and assumes that all pesticides pose unacceptable risks, but at the same time conceals the fact that the use of copper is the biggest poison for the soil in organic farming, or Mrs Hazekamp, who still talks about agricultural poison after a year of discussion. , or Mrs Rivasi, who continues to talk about scandalism, even though the report comes to the opposite conclusion. So I would like us to stop pitting the environment and agriculture against each other, because they go hand in hand. We need more innovation for more efficient and sustainable products, and this must be supported by the policy framework that the European Commission also sets, Commissioner. We all have the same objective: a reliable authorisation procedure. And I believe that we are now improving this with these recommendations. I would like the Commission to take up our proposals.

name: Bart Staes
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, First of all, I would like to thank Co-Rapporteur Lins, the shadow rapporteurs and Chairman Andrieu for the way in which we have worked constructively together.  I think that this report ultimately shows that Parliament is listening to its citizens. I think that in times of polarisation, in times of populism, we have shown that even in spite of the fact that we sometimes have different views on food production and agriculture, we can still come up with a blueprint for an objective, transparent, independent authorisation procedure for pesticides and plant protection products.  That is, ladies and gentlemen, what citizens are asking for. Not about politicians shouting, shouting, but about politicians who are trying to work constructively together and who are trying to bridge differences in vision.  The importance of human and animal health is always central, the importance of respect for our ecosystems, the public interest. Not the commercial, private interests of a few.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 16 January 2019. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – In December 2017, the licence for the controversial glyphosate-containing herbicide was renewed and authorised for use in the EU for a period of five years. This is, yes, a shorter than usual period (10 years), but it still causes me concern, especially in the context of the san francisco court ruling on August 11, 2018. The court found that 46-year-old gardener Dewayne Johnson, who had been using Roundup for years, had cancer of the lymphatic system due to exposure to glyphosate. According to the court, the Monsanto group (bought in July 2018 by the German pharmaceutical group Bayer) deliberately concealed the harmfulness of the substance and must now pay almost $290 million in damages to the gardener, to whom doctors give two more years to live. The court's verdict points to crushing evidence of the harmfulness of glyphosate. Germany's Bayer intends to appeal against that decision. However, if this judgment persists, it could lead to a wave of similar decisions as a precedent. I believe that the continued circulation of glyphosate is not only controversial, but above all dangerous for human health and life. This is of widespread public concern and therefore new, comprehensive analyses and evaluations of this product should be carried out at all. Active substances which cannot be shown to meet the strict approval criteria provided for in the legislation should be continuously removed from the market.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. – I was not one of the 100 000 members of the PEST Special Committee. In general, I believe that issues should be addressed within standing committees and not on ad hoc committees. Special committees always tend to be more politicized and ideologized on the issue. However, in the case of leaving the PEST Committee, I can congratulate our PPE faction, which has ensured that this text is balanced and realistic. It calls for greater independence and expertise in pesticide authorisation procedures, which is certainly appropriate. It is good that a review of the glyphosate issue will be launched. Nor do I have any objection to the claim that the use of plant protection products for the purpose of drying the crop before harvesting is inappropriate from the point of view of human health.

name: Tom Vandenkendelaere (PPE)
text: Written. – I voted in favour of the report on the authorisation procedures for plant protection products. The recommendations in the report are balanced for me and can significantly improve the authorisation procedure for plant protection products. However, we must also bear in mind that the European authorisation procedure for plant protection products is already one of the best procedures in the world.  The recommendations include a public register for all studies and data in an accessible format, public access to all scientific studies published before the European Food Safety Authority makes its judgment, more financial resources for the European Food Safety Authority, the Commission's designation of the rapporteur Member State to assess an active substance, the inclusion of long-term toxicity in the data necessary for the risk assessment of plant protection products , the strengthening of the post-marketing assessment and the launch by the Commission of an epidemiological study on the effects of pesticides on human health. If the European Commission complies with all these recommendations, I believe that this will both increase consumer confidence in the use of plant protection products and significantly reduce health risks to farmers.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Mr Monteiro de Aguiar, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2006/1/EC on the use of unrelated cars. road haulage vehicles (COM(2017)0282 – C8-0172/2017 – 2017/0113 (COD)) (A8-0193/2018).

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner, dear Commissioner Bulck, I congratulate the Romanian Presidency first of all for taking over the presidency and I also ask that you support this dossier so that we can close it further in this mandate. The proposal that we will vote tomorrow on the use of driverless hire vehicles in road freight transport - included in the first mobility package - aims to adapt a directive which has been in force for 25 years and thus gradually accommodate the market for the use of these vehicles, obviously adapting it to the needs of industry operators and taking into account the developments in the transport market itself. What we propose is that Member States should not limit the use of a rental vehicle by a company established in another Member State within its own territory, provided that the vehicle obviously meets the needs and standards of operation and safety. In this way, we have unlocked the potential of a rental and leasing market, which is composed, as you know, mostly of small and medium-sized enterprises and which obviously prospects the possibility of creating more jobs.  However, in order to avoid market distortions, obviously due to the existence of different levels of taxation, member states can limit, on their territory, the use of vehicles rented by an undertaking established in another Member State or in a period of time or in the total number of vehicles rented, provided that it authorises at least four consecutive months the use of this vehicle in their territory or , on the other hand, limit the number of vehicles rented to 25% of the total fleet of this company. And if the fleet consists of more than one or less than four vehicles, authorise the rental of at least one vehicle. For the correct implementation of this legislative act, we propose that all information on the rental vehicle be placed in the national electronic registers and that the exchange of information between Member States be carried out through the internal market information system, as well as the proposal found in other dossiers of the mobility package itself. With this proposal we will allow the single market to be implemented in this particular area, without doing so abruptly, and also by achieving compliance with social rules and market rules, especially in the transport of Goods from the Union. That is why I appeal to all colleagues is that they do not support amendments that discriminate against own vehicle rental vehicles and create even more obstacles to the development of this sector and the realisation of the single European transport area. to say "no" to exceptions blocking a greener, greener, safer fleet, such as restrictions on vehicles weighing more than six tonnes; to say 'no' to measures that block operators' needs to be able to respond on seasonal peaks and say 'no' to proposals on workers, because we are effectively referring to a directive that explicitly says 'no drivers'. Moreover, all vehicles put into circulation in the Union must comply with the established emission limits and we must therefore not create European legislative redundancies that say 'no' to the amendment of legislative acts, through this we cannot change them through others and tomorrow we will vote on this report for the transport market.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN) and particularly Ms Monteiro de Aguiar and the shadow rapporteurs for this overall balanced and well-drafted report on the Commission’s proposal to update the rules relating to the use of hired goods vehicles. The use of hired vehicles instead of vehicles owned by transport operators increases the efficiency of these operators. It represents an attractive alternative to the purchase of potentially under-used vehicles. What is more – and this is an increasingly important aspect – hired vehicles are usually newer, cleaner and safer than the vehicles owned by the operators. The average age of hired vehicles is significantly below the average age of the vehicles that are owned by the operators. They usually meet the latest environmental and safety standards. Hired vehicles are hence good both for road safety and the environment. The revision of the rules relating to the use of hired goods vehicles aims at removing outdated restrictions and those facilitating the use of these modern and clean vehicles. In addition, we want to ensure that operators may also use vehicles they have hired outside their countries of establishment and give them legal certainty when they do that. When you hire a vehicle, you should be able to use it anywhere in the EU and not be subject to different restrictions depending on where you are operating. To avoid unwanted consequences such as the large-scale flagging-out of fleets, the use of vehicles hired in another Member State may be limited to some extent, but those limitations should still allow operators first to meet in particular short-term, seasonal or temporary demand peaks, or to replace defective or damaged vehicles whenever this occurs. These are examples where our research has found that the possibility to use vehicles hired abroad would be most needed. Ms Monteiro de Aguiar’s report is right in moving possible restrictions on the use of hired vehicles from Article 2 to Article 3 of the Directive. This ensures that Member States will not be able to restrict the use of a hired goods vehicle on their territory if the use of that vehicle is allowed on the territory of the Member States where the operator using it is established. In other words, as long as you can use a hired vehicle in your home country, you can use it everywhere in the EU. The amendments that have been tabled for the plenary vote tomorrow are to a large extent also acceptable to the Commission. However, I have to mention specifically two amendments which could destroy the delicate balance created by Ms Monteiro de Aguiar. First, one amendment would allow a Member State to restrict the use of hired vehicles by a foreign operator that do not meet the latest environmental standards. One of the arguments in favour of the use of hired vehicles is that they are usually newer and cleaner than other vehicles. This should hence not be a big issue. However, such a provision would destroy the legal certainty created by Ms Monteiro de Aguiar’s report, as it would allow Member States to apply different restrictions to hired vehicles. You would first have to check where you could drive with your hired vehicle depending on where you want to use it, while no such restriction would apply to vehicles owned by operators. Another amendment which raises concerns is the one allowing Member States to restrict the use of hired vehicles for own-account operations. We have found that in the few countries where such restrictions are currently applied we have more empty runs. Moreover, this provision leads to a patchwork of legal rules in the Member States and has no legal certainty for companies using hired vehicles. Having said this, we can accept all the other amendments which increase the information provided to drivers and which strengthen compliance with and enforcement of the directive. I am looking forward to all the comments from your side.

name: Theresa Griffin
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, on behalf of Lucy Anderson, hired vehicles are an important and growing part of the EU road transport sector and one that touches on a range of public policy. This plenary has already taken an initial view on the revision of the law on hired vehicles, but it is right now that we reconsider the matter urgently, not least in the light of the controversial mobility package proposals. We must put safety, environmental concerns and consideration for truck drivers at the top of our list of priorities for this sector. The S&D has tabled a number of important amendments and these are supported by many MEPs from other political groups. Despite repeated attempts to find compromise solutions on issues such as the training of drivers, the environmental impact of hired vehicles or on the level of liberalisation of the market, the rapporteur has shown little willingness, I’m afraid, to accommodate different views, leaving us with a weaker text. I would urge everyone to support our amendments in the vote tomorrow in order to tackle the deficiencies of the proposal and provide a good basis for negotiations with the Council. It is essential that we ensure that hired vehicles are in compliance with the most applicable emission limits laid down in Union law. In the light of safety considerations and different circumstances in the Member States, it is right they should be allowed to decide whether or not to continue hiring restrictions on the heaviest goods vehicles. We strongly urge support for a sensible amendment to ensure that drivers receive the necessary information for using hired vehicles. Penalties applicable for infringements of this directive should be adequate, effective and dissuasive. And finally, breaches of the law regarding hired vehicles should be regarded as serious infringements of EU road transport legislation, leading to potential action being taken against the licences of infringing transport operators. Given these concerns, Madam President, the S&D Group cannot support the current text if it remains unamended.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, this dossier deals with a very difficult balance between, on the one hand, freeing up the European rental market for trucks with a more efficient business as a positive effect, and, on the other hand, the proper regulation of the same rental market for reasons of possible unfair competition, fiscal autonomy and security. It pleads for the rapporteur that she has found this balance right. The further liberalisation of the internal market will be accompanied by the necessary conditions. In doing so, Member States retain the ability to regulate their own business without distorting the European market. name: Matthijs van Miltenburg
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, the use of rented vehicles for the transport of goods has great advantages for Europe. The use of rented vehicles increases the productivity and flexibility of affected companies. Peak loads can be collected with rented vehicles. In addition, the use of rented vehicles reduces waste of capital because there is less underutilisation of vehicles. Moreover, rented vehicles are often newer, cleaner and safer, so the use of rented vehicles contributes to sustainability.  I am therefore in favour of a further liberalisation of the European market for rented vehicles. In this way, we can promote a level playing field and fair competition between European companies and remove unnecessary constraints and administrative burdens.  I would like to stress that proper registration of registrations of rented vehicles is essential, for example in order to enforce the rules on cabotage. Information should be able to be exchanged between authorities in different Member States, so that it is always clear what the carrier's country of establishment is. The text that we are voting on tomorrow includes a very good provision for this.  The same applies to the possibility of limiting the use of rented vehicles from another Member State. For example, to prevent rental companies from moving to countries with a more favourable tax environment.  In conclusion, there is a very balanced text to vote on, which will ensure a better functioning market for rented lorries in Europe. I support this text, because it puts the European transport sector on the right track.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Angelika Mlinar on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality on Gender Mainstreaming in the European Parliament (2018/2162(INI)) (A8-0429/2018).

name: Angelika Mlinar
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, let me begin by thanking all the shadow rapporteurs, as well as the policy advisors and the assistants, for excellent cooperation on this report. Gender mainstreaming, as we all know – or at least those of us who are in favour of it – is a globally accepted strategy for promoting gender equality. Gender mainstreaming is not an end in itself, but it is a strategy, an approach and a means to achieve the goal of gender equality. Gender mainstreaming involves ensuring that gender perspectives and attention to the goal of gender equality are central to all – and I would really would like to reiterate this – activities: policy development, research, dialogue, legislation, planning, implementation and monitoring of spending programmes and projects themselves. In 2019 I think it is unacceptable that, although the population of the European Union consists half of women and half of men, the composition of this House of the European Parliament does not mirror this balance, as only 36.1% of all MEPs are female. As the standing rapporteur for the gender mainstreaming report, I therefore encourage the European political parties and their party members to ensure a gender-balanced representation of candidates for the elections of this year’s European Parliament election by means of a zipped list or other methods such as parity lists. The same goes for the Secretariat of the European Parliament. Although women constitute 59% of the staff of this Parliament, they are still under-represented in all ranks of management, and the number of women in senior management positions has even decreased since June 2017, while the number of women in middle management roles increased only slightly. I regret that female representation in Parliament’s key decision—making positions at political and administrative levels still remains low and I urge Parliament to work towards a gender-equal distribution of decision-making positions. I am very confident that the pool of very capable women eligible for such posts is in fact big enough to successfully fill the vacancies when they arise. We need to change the conceptual and behavioural attitudes towards a culture of equality. Moreover, the European Parliament must live up to its values and promote inclusiveness. This report calls for an active inclusion of the rights and the well—being of the LGBTQI community. The European Parliament must pay attention to the rights of all gender identities. On the fight against sexual harassment, the report emphasises that sexual harassment is a serious crime, an extreme form of gender-based discrimination and one of the biggest obstacles to gender equality. I strongly regret the slow and inadequate progress in the implementation of the recommendations of Parliament’s resolution from 2017, such as mandatory training for MEPs and staff on preventing sexual harassment and the setting-up of a task force of independent external experts to examine the situation of sexual harassment in the European Parliament and the functioning of its two harassment committees. In this context, I would like to stress once again that gender equality is not just a women’s issue. In fact men may have a greater responsibility to work towards it as a group with collectively more power and influence in the European Parliament than women. A strong continued commitment to gender mainstreaming is needed in order for the European Parliament to support the promotion of gender equality at all levels. Therefore, I really hope for your support and a positive vote tomorrow.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank Ms Mlinar for her second report on gender mainstreaming and the work of the European Parliament for this legislature. For the EU and its institutions, gender mainstreaming is not a choice. It is an obligation. It is in the Treaty. It is in the acquis. It is in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Gender equality is still not a tangible reality for all. Indicators are stagnating. If there is any change towards more equality, it is often quite marginal. This also true unfortunately for EU institutions. The gender balance among the Members of the European Parliament has hardly changed since 2009, from 35% to 36.4%, and women currently account for 32.1% of European Commissioners, or nine out of 28. Within the European Parliament, the share of women in senior or middle management positions also remains low. In a democracy, gender equality in political office matters. More gender balance in EU institutions can increase citizens’ trust in the EU and improve the functioning of our democracies. Indeed, as Ms Mlinar has stressed, this year political parties and the Member States have a chance to show their commitment to gender equality and ensure a balanced representation of women and men in the European Parliament and in the top positions of the European institutions. I reiterate my plea for gender balanced nominations. Public administrations must be in tune with the people they serve. At the beginning of the mandate of this Commission, President Juncker set an in-house target of 40% women in middle and senior management by the end of the mandate. By 1 November 2018, women accounted for 37% at senior management level in the Commission, while at middle management level, the target of 40% has already been met. The progress comes after sustained efforts to identify, develop and support female talents through targeted initiatives. Besides taking stock of the progress during the legislature, the report sets the scene for the next one, and I very much welcome this forward-looking approach. As you know, the Commission’s strategic engagement for gender equality has been our framework for promoting gender equality and gender mainstreaming in the EU and beyond. It ends in 2019, together with the term of this Commission. So in 2019, we are also taking stock of the progress, identifying gaps and contributing to setting priorities for the future. In this context, the views of Parliament are very welcome. (Applause)

name: José Inácio Faria
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate my colleague Angelika Mlinar on the excellent work she has done in the gender mainstreaming in the European Parliament report, of which I have had the honour of being one of the shadow rapporteurs and which reflects well this Parliament's commitment to promoting more equal treatment.  I would like to mention that in October 2017 I had the opportunity to condemn the case that became known here in this House as "the Harvey Weinstein scandal, the consequences of which have also reached this Parliament. But despite the various civil society movements that have been denouncing situations identical to this, the fact is that we continue to silence situations of sexual harassment by colleagues and staff members in this Parliament. Ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the time has come to say enough, and to do so, I hope that strengthening the powers of the Advisory Commission on Sexual Harassment can help to end the still-remaining culture of fear and that we finally have a genuine zero-tolerance policy in the face of this kind of behaviour. If it is true and absolutely necessary to recognise that, at the root of these behaviours, the marks of inequality persist in the relations of power between men and women, it is also crucial for me that recruitment and selection for places with decision-making responsibilities are made on the basis of merit and competence and not only, or mainly, on the basis of criteria of positive discrimination.  Although there have been some differences between the various political groups during the preparation of this report on systems such as the imposition of gender quotas on the lists for this year's European elections and the inclusion of the gender perspective in all dimensions of the European Union budget, the truth is that the final document we will vote on tomorrow is quite ambitious and balanced and mirrors our conviction in a fairer and more fraternal Europe , where equal opportunities are not only a mirage but there is something we can be proud of. For all this, I call on all colleagues to vote in favour of this document, which I am sure will contribute to fostering parity and the balance of representation between women and men in the next parliamentary term in this Parliament.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate my colleague Angelika Mlinar, because this report is committed to a pedagogical method par excellence to curb inequality; a procedure that very aptly sums up the phrase of "preach by example". Because concrete measures are proposed here to make the European institutions an example in terms of equality, not just for what they say, but for what they do. Therefore, incorporating more knowledge, sincerely and honestly evaluating what we do inwards, and driving another way of doing with political and budgetary commitment to foster parity is essential to truly become a reliable benchmark with full legitimacy. The reflection that is defended here and the measures that are realized are a necessity, they are not a whim. Because in these seats there is no balanced representation between men and women; because we also do not see this parity in the selection and appointment of the people who lead our administration; because we continue to record some incidents of harassment in which the sexist component, along with abuse of power, detract from our efforts with reports and legislation to make the effects of inequality disappear; because we continue to fail in the basics of our institutional communication. I myself had to write to the President of Parliament because the iconic representation of European citizenship that starred in a very visible campaign, which was placed in Luxembourg Square, was basically male. Here, in short, the problems that sexism produces in areas such as labour, social rights or security are represented. Moreover, this report is not just a collection of successful proposals. It's a commitment to real leadership: another of our institutional missions. Inequality is the result of internalized values in many subconscious. It is the result of stereotypes that prompt many people to consider normal aberrant situations. Driving change needs a committed attitude from each of us and us who dismantle these outdated schemes based on proposals, actions and results. In short, credible references, initiative, coherence and continuity of our institutional action. Let us hope that the far-right populism, which wants to return us to the past, which openly defends inequality and underestimates gender-based violence will not succeed in turning this project into wet paper in the coming elections.
