You don't have to force people to hire or introduce a woman because she's a woman, you have to hire a woman or put a woman in elections or higher positions because she's capable of doing that, and that's it.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Madam President, in 1453, in Constantinople besieged by the Turks, the sex of angels was being talked about. In 2019, in a european Union in disable, there is a dissertation on the gender of MEPs. The text on gender equality has all the usual flaws in this Parliament. It is wordy, with three pages of visas and more than 30 recitals. It condenses the characteristics of the so-called "political correctness" in this regard. It stems from the idea that the roles of men and women, naturally complementary, must be in everything, always, everywhere, absolutely identical. The only thing that matters to you is that there are absolutely as many men as women everywhere, regardless of vocations, tastes, abilities, sensibilities of each other. Parity everywhere, but then, how do you count the third, fourth, fifth genders, and what place for those LGBTI, which you have also in your mouth, if I dare say? The result is a guilt and infantilisation of all Members and, of course, men.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Dear! Let me start by commenting, because I am a little surprised that the importance of such a thing as breaking down gender stereotypes is questioned in this House. If, 100 years ago, the first suffragettes had not broken down gender stereotypes, you would not have been chaired, the Commissioner would not have represented the Commission, and we Female Members would not have spoken in this House, because there would simply be no women here at all. So I think it's worth remembering what's happened over the last 100 years. As far as the report is concerned, I congratulate Angelice Mlinar on this very good report. I have no doubt that gender mainstreaming, or mainstreaming, is crucial for us to achieve the objective of equal treatment between women and men , an objective that is enshrined in many points in the Treaties, in many European directives and regulations. If we want to achieve this objective, if we want to effectively encourage nation states to make an effort in this area, it is clear that all the EU institutions with the European Parliament at the forefront should lead by example, show how the implementation of the principles of equal treatment can look like in practice for a particular institution. The report contains many legitimate demands and evaluations of actions already carried out, such as increased staff and funds to combat harassment in the European Parliament, or the improvement of information, guides on equal treatment. The report calls for closer cooperation between parliamentary committees, which is justified, is at the heart of what we call gender mainstreaming on gender equality, and for the Institute for Equality between Women and Men to be more involved in promoting information and tools to measure gender equality in national parliaments and in the European Parliament. (The speaker refused to listen to the question raised by Dobromir Sośnierz raising the blue card)

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, first of all, good year. Tell the honourable Member that we no longer have men in the Women's Committee because they do not want to, including in their own group. It should be noted that in 2003 the European Parliament undertook to adopt an action programme for gender mainstreaming, including the functioning of its committees and delegations. 16 years later, we're here discussing the same subject. We are in fact underrepresented.  It has already been said that 36% of the members of this Parliament are women and this is a blatant case of a lack of gender perspective. And I would like to mention the case of the Socialist Portuguese which, for the second time in a row, will present a fully paritarian list of the European elections and it would be good for other Member States to follow suit within their parties. It also said that in 2017 seven women were part of the composition of Parliament's table, a total of twenty members. Less badly, we can say, but as far as the leadership positions of this institution are concerned, we are at 33%. The data, in fact, does not pay in our favor.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: Thank you very much, Congresswoman. I give the floor to Mrs Wiśniewska. I saw Mr Sośnierz applying for a blue card again. I'm going to call you into your speech soon anyway, so don't let me give you that opportunity right now. Mrs. Wiśniewska, order.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for I would like to say that this report on gender mainstreaming in the European Parliament really has little to do with its title. If we were indeed to really focus on gender issues, one of the main, as not the main, topic would be the question of combining work and family life – women face this problem. I am surprised that this report does not reflect this real problem. Women want to be mothers, they want to raise children, they also want to develop professionally, so our role should be to create regulations that allow women to combine roles.  Women are smart, well educated and don't need special forums to win positions. The serious problem is that our assistants work in Parliament from nine o'clock to 6pm, so in fact, the most serious problem for them is precisely the combination of the role of mother and the role of employee.  You are surprised that there are so few men on the FEMM committee, and I am not surprised, because this committee is dominated by the populism of the far left, which makes equality policy, women's rights policy, ridiculed and caricatured by the left of parliament's political scene.  (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". – Mrs Winiewska, a brief question to you: are you aware that the title of the report is 'Gender mainstreaming in the European Parliament' and does not concern 'reconciliation of work and family life' or any other x-any subject? It is customary here in this House for a report to also talk about the subject itself and not about other very, very important issues as well.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Madam President, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. Both the Commissioner and the rapporteur have just pointed out that there is a small proportion of women in senior positions in the European Parliament. My diagnosis is this – because it is not possible to combine the professional work of men and women, women build their career path more freely. By the way, I would like to point out that this report provides mandatory training for Members and staff to prevent harassment. Do you misjudge Members and staff so badly that they need to be taught how to prevent harassment? Why are you surprised that no one comes to this training? After all, these trainings really offend, cultural people simply do not do such things, these are criminal actions and should be prosecuted on the basis of the criminal codes of the Member States.

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Gender mainstreaming in public matters is called sexism, so the title of this report should be 'Report on sexism in the European Parliament' so that everyone knows what it is really about. If we wonder where some negative stereotypes about women come from, perhaps from writing such nonsensical reports as this. It is really a shame for normal women that feminists in the European Parliament are demanding that women be employed in some positions simply because they are women. This feminism is a disgrace to women. In paragraph 40, of course, the rapporteur wants to silence uncomfortable statements with sanctions. It supports the fact that sanctions have been imposed here for statements that it does not like. So I wanted to say that I am not afraid of your punishments. You will not drown out the truth with penalties. You can impose these penalties on yourself, but I or Mr Korwin-Mikke are accountable to the voters, not to you, to the hypocricy, and you will not tell us what we are allowed to say in this Parliament and what we must not say – neither you nor Mr Tajani. You should withdraw from this Parliament if you do not understand what freedom of expression is and you, Mr Tajani, should resign.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: – According to the submitted text, I should address you gender neutral. However, I have no choice in my native language: I have to decide whether to address you as women or as men. And neither members of this House nor its leadership nor its interpreters have the right to change the political orders to change speech that has naturally evolved for hundreds, perhaps thousands of years. Such demands for the introduction of some absurd measures compromise efforts to achieve real equal opportunities in the Environment of the European Parliament. And not just the European Parliament. Worse still, meaningful initiatives such as improving the position of women in the working environment, zero tolerance for sexual harassment or valuing the work of women and men, regardless of gender, are also overshadowed. My 14 years of experience in European politics clearly show that we repeat this subject every parliamentary term, but at the same time show that the use of terms that people do not understand is particularly harmful to women. If we were to speak clearly about respect for the human dignity of every person, about the equal status of women and men, the position of women in society could be on a completely different level.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I am happy that this Parliament takes the fight for gender equality seriously. At a time when conservative forces are allying against women, girls and LGBTIQ+ people, it’s important to redouble our efforts towards achieving true gender equality. As we consider how to better add a gender perspective, both to the EU’s policies and the administrative functioning of Parliament, it’s important to keep in mind that this is not only about women. A gender perspective is also important for LGBTIQ+ people whose experiences are often silenced and ignored in policy-making. We still have a long way to go in terms of diversity in the European Parliament. White, middle-class people remain unacceptably over-represented in our institutions. The EU needs to adopt real policies fostering diversity and inclusion in order to create a real democracy where everyone is represented. One of the ways that I have been addressing this is to offer job-shadowing opportunities to young women and LGBTIQ+ people. Hopefully, some of them will be sitting in this Chamber in the future. Those of us who have achieved in life should never pull up the ladder behind us. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I would like to protest against the determination that conservatives are enemies of women and girls because it is an unauthorised abuse, and I would ask you not to use these kinds of terms, because that is stigmatization, and that is simply not true. On the other hand, I would like to kindly ask you how you believe that gender-neutral language can increase the chances of women and girls, because you are proposing the introduction of gender-neutral language.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I am very surprised when I read the draft text on page 17, paragraph 40, as you make a rebuke to the Court of Justice of the European Union in this draft text and, on the other hand, stand behind what appears to be an illegal decision by the President. The fact is that the court of the European Union has condemned and overturned the unacceptable attacks on freedom of expression in this House. The politically correct censorship of you on the left side of the Chamber has thus received a resounding slap in the face. While you are constantly rushing against Hungary, Poland and now Romania and openly discriminating against these states, this draft text is an attempt to interfere in the work of the Court of Justice of the European Union and to patronise the judges. They must respect and respect the recent court ruling, which is a victory for freedom of expression. Fortunately, there are more and more voices who, like me, reject your perverse denial of natural genders and the associated negation of the diversity of each person and dare to say so openly. Yes, for me a family consists of husband, wife and children. Europe will only have a future if we finally reverse the abnormal policy of hyper-individualisation and recognise that gender is more than social constructs.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to recall that the last report on gender mainstreaming in the work of the European Parliament was discussed here in 2016, which included a call for parity representation in the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. However, almost three years have passed and not much has changed in this respect. We are nowhere near equal representation in this committee, which should be symbolic of the European Parliament.  I think that if we do not achieve this goal, it is very smiling, let me say, unfortunately, even hypocritical, that we want to lecture others on the need for a balanced representation of women and men. We ourselves cannot achieve this in a committee to address this very objective. I recall the numbers – 7 men out of 33 full members, 10 men out of 29 alternates. That is not really equal representation. I consider this, the establishment of this committee and the discussion of such reports, unfortunately only as a certain alibi.  We have a strategy, we have a report, we have a resolution, but basically nothing substantial will change. I think our goal really must be gender equality. Protecting women in their natural role – and that's the maternal role. Let us support women to develop their professional careers, support women in their dignified lives, in their maternal role, so that they can properly care for their families.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The objective of equality is already in the founding treaties of the European Union, which means that it is part of the DNA of the European Union.  It's always about the same thing: meeting on an equal footing and sharing power. Obviously, in the far right corner of this House, some people are having a very difficult time. What is particularly important to me about the report is the practical. What can we implement in the future? For me, it is particularly important that the MeToo campaign should not only leave a hashtag, but that we also take action in this House – in the European Parliament – and that is to set up independent external experts, to which, at best, supposed victims can turn without being afraid. This includes, of course, compulsory training. Money is also important to me: when it comes to the EU budget, half-half – that is, gender budgeting – is to be introduced.  Congratulations to the rapporteur, who has done all the work and to all those who have pulled together.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Dear Chairman, when it comes to gender mainstreaming in the European Parliament, it is difficult not to start with numerous testimonies of sexual harassment of women in this institution. Every sexually harassed person must have all institutional protection and we must not send a message to women that they have to endure disgusting behavior to achieve a career. It is also a regrettable fact that many women do not get the seats they deserved simply because they are women, but no less devastating would be hiring people based on their gender alone. As a police officer myself, I was a victim of discrimination, but I fought and fought for my place among my male colleagues fairly and equally. We have European elections coming up and the composition of this house will change a lot, and there will be changes among the administrative staff. European citizens need the most capable, working, courageous, innovative and uncouth members and administrators. What gender they are, that's a lot less important.

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, what do we seem to be doing here today, revolution? Wouldn't you say so? And yet, the first revolutionary thing one can and none can do is always loudly proclaim what is happening. Rosa Luxemburg said so. Today's report tells aloud a reality that the majority does not imagine to be true in the European Parliament: inequality! How many positions in the European Parliament are women? Just 36%! And not to mention genders that aren't even represented. We urgently need balanced representation of candidates in elections and high office, education and information on impartial and non-stereotypical behaviour towards women and the LGBTI community.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: Madam President, God created man and woman in the image and likeness. We did not expect foreigners to preach to us the equality that the ancient Greek secretariat and Greek Orthodox Christianity have been teaching for millennia. It is an oxymoron that brussels bureaucrats, who are so cut off for diversity, are trying to convince them of the absolute equation and elimination of any physiological difference. Fundamental rights and basic rules of moral order become a vehicle for political exploitation to promote specific rhetoric. Yes to equality, not the elimination or abolition of the sexes. Yes to equal opportunities, not to institutional discrimination and coded acceptance of racism and sexism. Yes to meritocracy, no more favouritism in favour of certain elites. The formal achievement of objectives and the procedural fulfilment of criteria is not progress. We insist on real progress, on eliminating exploitation, abuse and sexual harassment through sensible and effective actions.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, first of all we must say that gender equality is a social issue and, therefore, there must be social policies in order to lead to gender equality. Of course, there are also ideological perceptions and stereotypes that must also be addressed. On this basis, therefore, one must address the issue of gender equality. I will stick to the issue of ballot papers in the run-up to the European elections. In Greece it is predicted that at least one third of candidates must represent one of the sexes. This means that there can be more representation. There is, however, a suggestion in the report in the case of a list that says that gender order should be switched. I would say that the list is undemocratic behavior and undemocratic regulation. It is right to have at least 1/3 representation of any gender or even 50%, but from then on to elect on the basis of the system of cross preference whichever the voters themselves prefer. Therefore, to have equal representation of the sexes on the ballot papers and for the voters themselves to decide who to elect as an MEP in the next European elections.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Madam President, since the last century, gender equality has become a reality and women have taken their proper place not only in the field of work but also in the field of politics, as well as in the field of all other social activities. Many women, even today, have carried out and continue to perform very successful high-level tasks in enterprises, various organisations and other bodies. I would also remind you that many women have been and continue to be Prime Ministers and Presidents of their countries. So equality exists. As far as the European Parliament is concerned, and here we have equality, because 55% of the staff are women and as far as the issue of the representation of women in the upper echelons of the hierarchy is concerned, both the administrative and the political of the European Parliament, we should not treat the issue as a question of percentage as a matter of statistics but as a matter of meritocracy. There must be equal opportunities and high-responsibility positions to be occupied by as many as those with the required qualifications. If we do not look at this in the light I mentioned to you, then the whole affair will simply result in an expression of an unsatisfied desire.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – Madam President, I was just trying to catch your attention because you didn’t give me the opportunity to respond to the blue card from my colleague Wiśniewska, so this is just a way to get your attention. I do think I should answer, because the fight for women’s rights is a fight for all of us. I am very proud that in my political group we take that seriously and we put it at the forefront of our work in the Socialists and Democrats Group. However, it will not have gone unnoticed by anybody living in the 21st century, in the days that we are experiencing, that President Trump is the most arch-conservative leader that we have seen in decades, and that his influence on right-wing forces across the world means that women are not even keeping pace with the level of equality that we had before. Somehow or other, President Trump has normalised the kind of inequality, mistreatment, sexual harassment and misogyny that existed beforehand. He is a conservative and it is the conservative forces like that that we are now fighting against.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: Thank you very much, Congresswoman. I apologize for forgeting that it would have been a shame to make this great speech. And now I will give the floor on behalf of the Commission to Mrs Jourová, who, like our Parliament, is trying to do everything she can to egalitarianism for women. Thank GoodNess, very strong Commissioners control portfolios. Give me a call, Commissioner.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you very much for a very interesting discussion which went beyond the scope of the report. I will use the opportunity to also go beyond it and to present the main principles which the Commission and myself keep working on gender equality topic. The most important principle in my view is equality in opportunities – nobody says that men and women are the same. We speak about equality of opportunities, breaking the stereotypes which stop women from getting to managerial positions, and we all know that this is still an issue. So equality in opportunities. Then we come to zero tolerance for discrimination and violence against women. We have alarming statistical figures which show that both open discrimination and violence are problems which need to be solved. And the third principle, we have to unleash the potential of women in both the political and economic sphere, because this will be to the benefit of the whole of society. Again we have a lot of evidence which shows that it is a short-sighted position of society not to enable women to have managerial positions, to use their qualifications, because 62% of university leavers are women, young women who want to take over part of the responsibility of the development of our societies. And you mentioned many times that one of the issues which women face is insufficient conditions for working mothers to combine their work and family duties. That is why, keeping these principles, I want to continue until the end of my mandate and I very much count on the support of this Parliament to finish some of the things which we have started. Speaking about legislation, first of all, there is the work-life balance initiative, the combination of legislative and non-legislative measures which should create these better conditions for the working women and for working parents if you want to have this gender neutral, because we also here speak about the better possibility for men to share more duties at home and to give a wider spectrum of choices for families to use these better conditions, if they wish. We have to do everything we can to fight again discrimination, as I said, also by supporting civil society institutions. The equality bodies which we are proposing to strengthen their possibilities to represent the victims of discrimination in the courts for instance, to be concrete. We are doing a lot of things through the funding of various projects which should decrease violence against women. I am in permanent contact with the law enforcement authorities in all the Member States, where we have common clear understanding that violence against women, especially domestic violence, is a crime which has to be punished. I think we are doing everything possible to achieve the accession of EU to the Istanbul Convention. We are doing our best in promoting women to managerial positions through diversity charters, and are still also negotiating the possibility of the adoption of the women on boards directive. So there is still a lot of work ahead of us. We are still not at the end of the mandate and it will be very important that in the next mandate, here in this House, will be a lot of women and men who will understand that gender equality is not a choice. It is an obligation and that we have to solve this problem not as a problem of women but as a problem of our society. So let’s hope the elections will bring a lot of enlightened people to this House, but also to the Commission, who understand the core principles and the things which need to be done, either the continuation of what we are doing now or new ideas and new visions, and hopefully workable measures to be accomplished or to be used to solve the problem.

name: Angelika Mlinar
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, the Committee on Women’s Rights (FEMM) is a non-legislative committee. Since it was mentioned that there are not many men, I would say that this is one of the reasons why there are not so many men present. I’m also sorry for this, but this is a fact. Also, the gender mainstreaming report is a non-legislative report. However, this debate has shown once more how heated and how intense the discussion actually is here in this House when it comes to gender issues.  I would like to thank all colleagues for their contributions – the supporting voices as well as the critical ones – since an open debate is the basis of every good functioning democracy. So is the vote, and I therefore kindly ask for broad support in favour of this gender mainstreaming report tomorrow in order to have a clear democratic decision and a strong commitment by the European Parliament for gender mainstreaming and gender equality.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place on Tuesday 15 January 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – The European Parliament is committed to promoting gender equality, women's rights and diversity in its workplace and in implementing its policies. One way of promoting gender equality is to integrate the gender dimension into the work of the European Parliament. Gender mainstreaming is a generally accepted strategy for implementing gender equality. It is not a very objective, but a tool for ensuring gender equality, where a gender-based approach is guided by the design, development, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of policies, regulatory instruments and spending programmes. The EU recognises that gender equality is a fundamental right, a common value for the EU and a prerequisite for the Union to achieve its objectives of growth, employment and social cohesion. Gender mainstreaming should therefore be seen as a continuous process supported by systematic efforts to integrate the gender dimension at all levels, into all areas and at all stages of policy-making and implementation processes. This latest report gives an overview of the current situation in the European Parliament, both in its administration and in its policies. It is critical of the progress made over the last two years and makes concrete recommendations on how to further improve the situation.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D)
text: Written. – Will 2019 be the year we really tackle gender inequality? A hundred years ago, women were given the right to vote. Meanwhile, there is still no female Prime Minister and a woman at the top of an EU institution seems far away. It's time for more women to be at the top, and it's time for more room for men in the household and care. There is a lot of work to be done, but let us take up that glove and make a difference.  The structural obstacles that stand in the way of gender equality must be addressed. Tax policy should not be a whose control is inequality, but rather to combat it. Individual rather than double taxation is needed for a fairer distribution of paid and unpaid work. This will help close the 16% pay gap and the 40% pension gap.  I believe that the time has come for gender to become no longer a factor in a European's ambitions. I am calling for a Europe in which no one is disadvantaged in the pursuit of his or her dreams. For a Europe in which there is gender equality in top positions. Unfortunately, the Europe I am advocating is not yet there.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report on the European Joint Undertaking for Fusion Energy Development and ITER prepared by Marian-Jean Marinescu on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (2018/2222(INI)) (A8-0393/2018)

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, energy security is a strategic area for the Union and nuclear fusion is one of the future solutions for achieving this need. As Parliament's rapporteur on this dossier, I believe that funding for European participation in the ITER project, which concerns the production of electricity through nuclear fusion, must continue throughout the next multiannual financial framework. Europe has played a leading role in the ITER project, developed in close collaboration with the non-European signatories of the agreement. As rapporteur, I supported this project, convinced that the shift to fusion electricity will profoundly change the future in the field of energy globally. Six billion euros will be Euratom's contribution for the European Union to remain in the period 2021-2027 in this project. This six billion is nothing more than an investment in the Union's energy security. I regret that Parliament is not a co-legislator and that we only have an advisory role in this dossier. The European Parliament will continue to follow the progress of this project in the coming years, in particular through discharge reports. The allocated funds must be spent efficiently. The European Agency responsible must continue to work with the other partners so that there are no delays in the proposed programme or the overcoming of the costs assessed.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank my colleague Marian-Jean Marinescu for finding his draft report broadly acceptable and, after the vote in the ITRE Committee, it also includes many of the amendments I have tabled. In my opinion, adequate funding must be guaranteed to ITER, which to date is recognised globally as the most accredited experiment to demonstrate the feasibility of nuclear fusion. Europe must therefore continue to play a leading role in the project which, I believe, has great symbolic as well as scientific value. In Cadarache, in fact, the world's largest powers, countries that together account for more than half of the global population, collaborate effectively on the success of this great experiment and share its experimental results. It is necessary, and I would also like to add this , and this is well specified in the text that we have voted on and will vote on, for the organisation to continue along the path of improvement and rationalisation of management, if possible by preventing the road map from being disregarded and further delays and revisions of upward expenditure.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, the ITER programme, that is to say the European Joint Undertaking for the Development of Nuclear Fusion, is of particular interest. To say that at the moment, as mentioned, very important non-European states, such as the United States, Russia, Japan, China, South Korea and India, are working together. Of course, the European Union plays an important role and this shows that investing in the knowledge economy is particularly important. Of course, we must be careful not to miss the budget. We know that the procedures and the whole experiment are not easy. We know that there are often quite a few problems, but on the basis that we can really stick to this programme and, above all, in a way that does not escape financially but contributes at the same time to the development of the technology itself, it will be something particularly important. In this context, I would say that for certain aspects of this programme funding could also be given to Greek research centres and universities, so that they too contribute to this joint effort.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I am wrong about what has been said, because this ITER project is irrelevant as it comes too late. What does the IPCC say? He says that to solve the problem of global warming, we must be able to produce CO2-free electricity by 2050. However, the ITER project has fallen far behind and the first prototype to make electricity will not arrive until 2050. So we are spending a lot of money on a project that will come too late. Why a lot of money? Because at the beginning, we were told that ITER was 5 billion euros. It is 20 billion euros, and the U.S. Department of Energy has estimated the cost of ITER, with operation, at 65 billion euros. It's really oversized.  Moreover, it is a very disproportionate project. It is very centralized and there are a lot of technical problems. We want to try to put the sun in a box and we can't make the box. There are problems with disruption, etc.  As my colleague Marian-Jean Marinescu said, it is even an undemocratic project. We parliamentarians do not have codecision. The project is carried out under the Euratom Treaty and only the Member States decide.  Therefore, we still need to look at things rationally and, in my opinion, ITER is not the solution to global warming.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to say that nuclear energy is a low-carbon alternative to fossil fuels for most Member States of the European Union and is also a key composition for energy creation within their energy mix. It produces almost 30% of the EU's energy sources, and I would also like to point out that in 2018 the UN has issued a pro-nuclear report with a scenario on how to progressively continue to protect the environment before it is too late, with nuclear power always playing an essential role.  Here we are talking about a research project that is undoubtedly delayed, has its problems, is probably also late, the capital increases have to be paid precisely in view of the fact that the research, the fusion reactor part simply can be a very significant step forward and can kind of sucing us on how to meet the Paris climate targets, so I take note of this report with this that this delay is unmiss, but in any case represents for us a possible step forward.

name: John Howarth (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for a report that is perfectly sensible, as far as it goes. However, the obvious elephant in the room is the section that calls for clarification of the role of the United Kingdom. This does, of course, depend on the United Kingdom clarifying its own position. Unfortunately, our Prime Minister Ms May has made something of a mess of this, from the point where she said the UK wished to be outside of the Euratom Treaty. The Joint European Torus (JET) based at Culham in my constituency is the place – the only place – that has actually made fusion happen, and it is an essential source of expertise. Without the work of JET, the International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor (ITER) Project will be subjected to further disruption and delay. Before Mr Sam Gyimah, the UK’s last Science Minister, resigned over the mess that is the government’s Brexit negotiation, he announced the expansion of the Culham site, with more UK investment and more jobs. I would urge the Commission, when the opportunity arises, to resolve the uncertainty over JET and jobs at Culham as quickly as it can.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you very much for the fruitful discussions today and in particular the rapporteur, Mr Marinescu, for his report and its call to the Council to approve the Commission’s proposal to continue funding ITER over the course of the next financing period. As always, Parliament’s views and inputs are crucial to ensure effective European support for this important project. The energy transition and the fight against climate change constitute some of the greatest challenges we face today. In this context, it is essential to develop a low—carbon, environmentally friendly energy source that can work as a complement to renewables and fusion; as an energy source it holds a lot of promise. ITER, a device of unprecedented scale and sophistication at global level, hosted on European soil, is getting the best world expertise. The project aims for key scientific breakthroughs in the development of fusion as a low-carbon and virtually inexhaustible energy source that should support the EU’s objectives to fight climate change. It is already bringing many concrete benefits for the European economy and society at large, not least through enabling the European industry and research community to enter new markets and develop international cooperation. It is also extremely promising in fulfilling the other dimensions of our energy union to make energy secure for our citizens while supporting growth and job creation.  We want to ensure that Europe continues leading the way on fusion energy. This is why it is so valuable to have the support of Parliament for the project. Thanks to this leadership in the construction of ITER, Europe will be in a privileged position to reap the benefits of constructing and cooperating the first generation of fusion power plants.  The proposed report comes at an important time for the project. In recent years ITER has undergone significant management improvements, which have produced tangible results. The construction of the project needed for the start of experiments is now around 60% complete and the assembly stage of the project will soon start, paving the way for the first experiments in 2022. And to respond to Ms Rivasi’s contribution: it is true that the fusion will not be commercially available before the second half of the century and therefore does not enter into the portfolio of low-carbon technologies for our climate mitigation strategies up to 2050. However, climate change and decarbonisation of energy production are long-term challenges that will require viable and sustainable solutions, also post-2050. From that perspective fusion does offer attractive prospects for sustainable low-carbon energy strategies for the second half of the century, when fusion could come to represent a suitable complement to renewable energy sources.  The expected advantages of fusion in terms of low-cost fuel abundance and low environmental impact make its development worth pursuing from such a long-term perspective. All the international stakeholders in ITER are working hard to ensure that the project continues to make steady progress in accordance with the revised schedule that was set in 2016 and endorsed by the Council last year. With the continuous support of the European Union for the project in the next multiannual financial framework, the project should therefore reach crucial stages, contributing to building the energy, security and low carbon economy of tomorrow.

name: La Présidente. –
text: This item on the agenda is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, January 15, 2019. Written statements (Article 162)

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. – The world's energy consumption is growing at an astonishing rate and continuously. 50 years ago, we consumed a third more energy than we do today, and the International Energy Agency predicts that demand will increase by a further 30% over the next 20 years, so we have no choice but to settle in for a sustained capacity increase. We need to bring in more and more energy sources, while our current consumption is not sustainable. This is one of humanity's greatest current challenges, in which, on the one hand, we must ensure that more and more people can live better, while protecting our future so that the planet can remain liveable for future generations.  Such a radical challenge is likely to be answered only by a radical solution, since fine-tuning the existing system is probably not enough. Such a solution could be to release the energy inherent in fusion. It's clean, plentiful and ubiquit all over the place, but unfortunately technically it's not easy at all. Deciphering this mystery of nature is complicated and uncertain, but if it succeeds, it could solve our myriad problems in one fell swo down. I believe that it is important to properly support fusion research, in particular ITER. In these projects, decades of research by the world's leading scientists have accumulated immense knowledge, the value of which is invaluable to our future. Like all basic research, it does not promise precise deadlines or provide quality guarantees, but that is the evolution of science.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for the brief presentation of Brian Hayes' report on the assessment of how the EU budget is being used for public sector reform (2018/2086 (INI)) (A8-0378/2018) (The session is suspended for a few moments)

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would also like to point out this non-standard situation, that, for example, in the Czech Republic, the system of public administration has been reformed since its inception. This is a very gradual and complex process, and it is important to use the EU budget to reform public administration.  There is no doubt that, for example, the sources of cohesion policy should not replace a Member State where a national source of funding should be used, that is to say, stop treating it as an additional system, and, of course, this EU budget should again be focused primarily on the outcome. The positive impact of the use of this budget then also has an impact on the public administration of the Member States and the effect is then multiplied.  I would also like to point out that we should not only focus on the issue of funding a public report, but also on the exchange of information. It's an agenda that actually uses learning to share information with each other. These are the things I have taken the liberty of noticing without the rapporteur's report being made.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mr Hayes and my fellow shadow rapporteurs for their work on this report. In general, as Article 41 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights reminds us, citizens have the right to good and efficient administration and, although the European Union does not have direct regulatory competence with regard to the administrative organisation of the Member States, I believe it is important to ensure the best possible coordination of the resources that the Union budget provides for supporting the modernisation and administrative governance of the Member States. This is in order to allow the provision of services and to ensure the correct implementation of European policies of solidarity, cohesion and development. In my opinion, the promotion of e-government in relations between administration and the citizen is particularly important. The application of information and telematic technologies can now contribute not only to reducing waste, but above all to making it easier, more immediate and more transparent for citizens and businesses to have access to the services and funding opportunities offered by European funds.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, first of all I would like to point out that reforms in the public administration of the Member States are the responsibility of the Member States themselves and the European Union has no competence in this regard. I say this because the troika over the eight years in Greece imposed violent reforms on the public sector, intervening in areas where it had no competence and all this by blackmailing the Greek government that it would not give loans. With regard, of course, to the 9 billion that the European Union is giving to the reform of the public sector, I think that these should be used in the best way, not be an alibi for the European Union to intervene with choices of its own and, above all, Brussels, to place great emphasis in particular on the use of new technologies, to include not only central government but also local government. , to have an important role for national parliaments and to have an exchange of best practices.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Dear Chairman, the capacity and efficiency of public administration have a major impact on how the Member State will use the European resources available. Experience varies and some members are significantly more successful in this than others. In doing so, it should be said that there is no grand conspiracy and that the more unsuccessful members themselves are guilty of not using European funds as much as they could. On the other hand, it is our obligation to warn of failures, to propose solutions and to extend a hand so that their citizens can feel the benefits of membership as much as possible. From Croatian experience, I can say that the procedures for reaching European funds have been further complicated at the national level. However, the Structural Reform Support Programme, for which I was rapporteur, as well as other programmes relying on cohesion funds, can drastically change the situation for the better, as funding from a European level offers an opportunity for public administration at national, regional and local level to be educated, professionalised and better organised.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you very much for your initiative on a motion for a European Parliament resolution on assessing how the EU budget is used for public sector reform. On behalf of the European Commission, I welcome this initiative. I agree with Parliament’s analysis that, and I quote, ‘public administration in the Member States is fundamental to the implementation of the EU budget and, when it works effectively, can help to deliver modern systems that improve prosperity and welfare in the EU’. We also fully agree on the importance of well-coordinated support, exchange of best practices and close cooperation with the Member States. The Commission has already recognised several suggestions in Parliament’s report and is working to follow up on them. For example, by appointing the structural reform support service as policy coordinator for public administration and governance, we will be able to ensure an even higher coherence of the Commission’s work in this area. The service will also work on a benchmark for administrative quality, on pooling and disseminating knowledge and good practices and on a closer dialogue with the Member States in this area.  The Commission is managing and will manage a number of technical support activities and reform projects in the area of governance and public administration. Specific support is also provided under cohesion policy to improve the administrative structures of the Member States for the management of the European Structural and Investment Funds.  I believe we share a common interest with Parliament and, indeed, with the Member States to support the development of modern and quality administration throughout the EU.
