name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – This own-initiative report, based on the study 'Public sector reform: how the EU budget is used to encourage this reform' published in 2016, aims to recommend that Member States contribute to increasing administrative capacity and improving governance through electronic tools, thereby increasing citizens' access to public services. The study shows that the potential of eGovernment solutions could be one of the main objectives of EU-promoted public administration reforms, as they facilitate citizens' access to public services. Public administration in the Member States is essential for the implementation of the EU budget and, when it is working effectively, can help create modern systems capable of increasing prosperity and well-being in the EU. Furthermore, improving capacity and administrative governance at Member State level could accelerate better use of the EU budget.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for the brief presentation of Andrzej Grzyb's report on the direction of the European Union and the mandate of the EU's Special Envoy for the Promotion of Freedom of Religion or Belief outside the European Union (2018/2155 (INI)) (A8-0449/2018)

name: Andrzej Grzyb
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner Jurová, i would like to thank you for your comments. Mr Figel'. I would like to express my sincere thanks, above all, to the political groups, but also to the co-rapporteurs for supporting my initiative for Parliament to address the issue of freedom of religion and belief in the world, with recommendations for change for european Union policies in this area. The situation of freedom of religion and belief in the world is very special. It is deteriorating and it can be said that even we could say that the 21st century is also the age of the instrumentalisation of religions for political purposes. In 2018, we started work on the report, five years after the Council adopted guidelines for promoting and protecting freedom of religion or belief. We also had our own contribution, because Laima Andrikienė prepared a report. In a way, today we are also referring to progress in this area. It has also been two years since President Juncker, in response to a European Parliament resolution of February 2016, appointed a Special Envoy for Freedom of Religion and Religion. This function is performed by Ján Figel'. It is also the year in which we celebrated the 70th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. The European Parliament's draft report recalls the importance of the declaration of the right to freedom of religion and belief as a recognised international human right, a right defined in Article 18, which is also protected by Article 18 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. The legal order of the European Union itself should also be mentioned here. This year marks 10 years since the Entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon. Article 21 is human rights in external action, including freedom of religion and belief. Article 17 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union recognises the status of churches and religions and establishes an open, transparent and regular dialogue.  The report is systemic, horizontal. However, we pay particular attention to two cases, and here I thank you for supporting my amendments, which highlight the drama of the 2010 death sentence for alleged blasphemy against Islam by Christian Woman Asia Bibi in Pakistan. After her recent acquittal, we expect the Pakistani authorities to ensure her and her loved ones' safety. We hope that all this will be successful. We also condemn the imprisonment of the 2015 Sakharov Prize winner Raif Badawi for his alleged insult to Islam and call for his release. The main message of the report is that we are fighting for freedom of religion and belief for all. I would like it to sound good – freedom of religion and belief for all, because those who are most persecuted can benefit the most from it. Hard figures show that christians are the largest persecuted group. It is said that even more than 200 million. About 170,000 a year are killed. Parliament acknowledged this in its 2016 resolution on the mass murder of Daesh, describing it as genocide. Similarly, the US Congress has also confirmed this. This also applies to other minorities, such as the Yazyds. We also mention the Rohingya ethnic group in Myanmar. Many of these examples could be given here. We have adopted a number of recommendations in the report – first of all, we appreciate the achievements of the Special Envoy since 2016 and call on the Council and the European Commission to review the special envoy's mandate and provide adequate support to move from annual mandates to a multi-annual mandate, and to support the development of cooperation networks in all Union institutions and Member States. We also call for more effective implementation of the European Union guidelines, increased funding, training in the Union institutions for national diplomacy and also for Member States' diplomacy. We recommend that churches and religious associations be included in this process. We appreciate the financial support for projects dedicated to the promotion and protection of freedom of religion and belief from the Union budget, but we also point out that, in addition to the European Instrument for Democracy for Human Rights, these projects can be financed in the framework of conflict prevention, support for education and culture. We also call on the Council and the Commission to maintain adequate funding in the next financial perspective.  We note carefully the initiatives aimed at establishing an official International Day of the United Nations, which commemorates the victims and survivors of religious persecution. It is worth it for the European Union, whose founding acts place freedom of religion and belief among its fundamental values, to join an increasing number of countries supporting this initiative. I would like to emphasise here that the High Representative has also spoken very positively on this matter.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the principle of separation between State and Church is a guiding principle of the organisation of any democratic State which implies the rejection of any religious interference in the functioning of public institutions, as well as any public interference in religious affairs. For us Europeans, religious freedom, belief and conscience, more than rights, are universal basic values from which we can never give up, at the very point of the very essence of what we represent, a democratic, free and just Europe, losing every meaning. That is why this House has sought to honor the victims of religious persecution and conviction through the Sakharov Prize.  For all this, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate the Commission on its efforts to strengthen the promotion of freedom of religion and prevent religious extremism over the past few years, either through the European Union's overall strategy for foreign policy and security, or through the EU Action Plan on human rights and democracy. I end by saying that the creation of the post of Special Envoy for the promotion of freedom of religion or belief outside the European Union proved to be a very just bet by the Commission in the recognition of the primacy of freedom of religion or conviction in the face of the resurgence of religious fundamentalism.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, religious freedom and freedom of belief must be protected both inside and outside the European Union. This means that the various financial instruments that exist on the part of the European Union, such as the European Development Fund, the Development Cooperation Mechanism, the Pre-Accession Assistance Mechanism, must be given on condition that states that are outside the European Union and receive these funds respect the principle of religious freedom and freedom of belief. This is not the case with Albania where the rights of the Greek ethnic minority of the Northern Continent are suppressed, where they are not allowed to perform their religious duties, where churches such as the Church of Agios Athanasios are demolished. It therefore means that the European Union must stop all funding to Albania until it respects and respects the rights of the Greek ethnic minority in the North Continent.

name: Jordi Solé (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, every individual has the right to choose what to believe or whether to believe or not, and this right must be protected and preserved through the EU’s internal and external policies. On the one hand, we are happy to see that all dimensions of freedom of religion and belief have been reflected in the final report – not just religious freedoms, but also freedom of thought, conscience and belief. Also, references to the increasingly problematic fate of non-believers and atheists, as well as to the right of apostasy, to change religion or not to have a religion, were included in the report. On the other hand, we regret that the right to voice satirical or critical opinions of religions or religious authorities as a legitimate expression of freedom of thought or artistic creation wasn’t taken into account.  We also insist on the need for the Special Envoy’s mandate to be complementary and coordinated with that of the EU Special Representative on human rights so that any EU action on freedom of religion or belief is placed within the framework of EU’s human rights policy.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Madam President, yesterday we celebrated the 451st anniversary of the Act of Religious Tolerance and Freedom of Conscience in Transylvania – today Romania. In a Europe rife with violent religious conflict, this was the first declaration of this sort, laying down the basis of hundreds of years of peaceful and respectful co-existence. Sadly the general situation does not seem to be any brighter today. More than 70% of the global population suffers from restrictions of freedom of religion or belief, and we frequently see violent expressions of religious fundamentalism.  In this context, the creation of the position of the Special Envoy already carries the message that the EU is strongly committed to promoting religious freedom in the world. I also recommend taking a position with a multi-year term and developing its working networks with the other institutions. It is crucial that we implement the EU guidelines on freedom of religion or belief effectively, in order to advance these values worldwide in our foreign policy. Europe needs to set an example once again, as it did nearly 500 years ago.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab First of all, I want to appreciate the initiative of Andrzej Grzyb. I know him, so I know that he is putting his heart into supporting the defence of religious freedom, and I also know Ján Firel, so I know that he is working with the best commitment, but when we talk about this report, unfortunately it bears every possible trace that even the best political intention taken in today's European Parliament will be tainted by all the ideology that we see in this report. There was not a single word about Christianity on many pages. Let us remember, in the introduction to the Treaty on European Union, that the Union is inspired by Europe's religious heritage, but here it turns out that there is no specific heritage. These examples could be multiplied for a long time, but unfortunately this is not a good report.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, On the contrary, I would like to highlight Mr Grzyb's report because, in my opinion, it is indeed of very high quality, and we should realise that we stand on the principle of equality. This means equality between groups of believers and non-believers. While my colleague Jurek is right, I am also very sorry to see a certain incoherence in European policy, in the sense that we deal with and provide development aid often to states that persecute Christians. This is really not a good example. On the other hand, the way in which the European Union is elected, that it wants to establish a special envoy precisely on the issue of religious freedom, is very correct, and I want to support it, because religion is sometimes driven to two extremes today. Either religious groups are persecuted or religion is used as a political instrument. We should push our position, that is, equality of rights, but also guarantees of religious freedom, which is due to the European Charter, to which we certainly all subscribe.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I believe that the establishment of a special envoy to promote freedom of religion or belief outside the European Union is very important and is a good decision. It is also fortunate that the first person to hold this post since 2016 is Slovak diplomat and Christian Democrat Ján Figeľ. It was he who, together with Czech diplomats in Sudan, negotiated the release of Czech aid worker Petr Yašek. He was sentenced to twenty years in prison for documenting the persecution of Christians in Sudan. His release subsequently took place, and I believe that it was also the initiative of former Commissioner Figeľ, but also of the European Parliament and the Commission, together with Czech diplomacy, which helped to release Petr Yašek. There are still millions of convicts and persecuted persons, and it is important to continue to protect them.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Madam President, those who claim that history repeats itself should feel vindicated. Eighteen centuries after the end of the persecutions against Christians, they are unfortunately repeated in this day and age by various states in the Middle East, Asia and Africa. Christians are persecuted for their faith and more than 215 million have suffered all kinds of humiliations and persecutions. Even today, unfortunately, there are women and girls who suffer sexually for their faith in Jesus Christ. In Greece, which has 95% of the population of Orthodox Christians, there have been more than 556 incidents of attacks against religious sites, i.e. places of prayer. The European Union must crack down on this phenomenon and not finance countries that suppress religious freedoms and not accept countries such as Albania, which violates human rights.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE).
text: – Madam President-  Special envoy Ján Figel has a lot of work to do and he's doing a great job. With his work, the European Union is putting aside those who are at risk of one of the fundamental rights, and I think one more thing that Ján Figla's work has a positive feedback on the European Union, because through this work we have strengthened awareness of the importance of religious freedom in many countries in this world, and I would like that awareness to have more impact on our foreign policy. My question to Commissioner Jourova is how the European Commission intends to strengthen the role of special envoy.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first let me thank the rapporteur, Mr Grzyb, and Parliament for the good cooperation on this report. We very much share its spirit and the call to deepen our work on freedom of religion or belief outside the EU.  As the report stresses, freedom of religion or belief is dramatically under attack across the world. People of all faiths are being persecuted because of their beliefs. As the report stresses, discrimination based on faith is widespread. Legislative hurdles for registering religious groups are proliferating, as well as blasphemy and apostasy laws criminalising freedom of thought. As many of you stressed here, these are first and foremost violations of fundamental human rights embedded in the Universal Declaration that was approved just over 70 years ago. Faith cannot be imposed and it cannot be prohibited. The report stresses that these violations also undermine a society’s resilience. They hamper development and they foster instability and war. For these reasons, in the past year we raised our concerns about violations of religious freedom in more than 20 human rights dialogues with countries from the Middle East and North Africa and from several parts of Asia. Both the EU Special Representative for Human Rights and the Special Envoy for the promotion of freedom of religion or belief have been actively promoting this right worldwide. They both conducted several missions to engage with governments and religious actors.  I want to highlight the multilateral dimension of our work on this issue. The report underscores the necessity to keep working actively within the United Nations system and praises the current EU engagement. I can reassure you that in 2019 we will continue to honour this commitment. In all our dialogues we stress that all human rights are connected and that freedom of religion and belief must go together with freedom of expression, freedom of association and peaceful assembly, but also with women’s rights and LGBTI rights.  The report calls for stronger interinstitutional cooperation. Since the elaboration of the EU Guidelines on freedom of religion or belief in 2013, this has been a constant goal for our action. The best way to foster coordination is to have a common understanding of the tools available and the challenges we face. As the report emphasises, in order to achieve our common vision, we have multiplied training for our staff both in Brussels and delegations. In line with the report’s recommendations, we will keep engaging actively with religious leaders, scholars, faith-based organisations, non—believers and human rights defenders. The overall picture is not at all rosy, yet we still witness signs of hope. For instance, we have seen in 2018 some prominent freedom of religion and belief defenders freed from jail. In different parts of Africa faith leaders have led reconciliation dialogues. As we fight against the violations of freedom of religion and belief, we will also continue to support these signs of hope all across the world.

name: La Présidente. –
text: This item on the agenda is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, January 15, 2019. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. –One in 10 Christians in the world today suffers from some form of religious persecution—whether discrimination or serious violence. Religious persecution today takes many forms and grows stronger every day, while Christians are the most persecuted religious group in the world.  Every year, 255 Christians are killed and 104 kidnapped. Every year, 180 Christian women are raped, sexually assaulted or forced into marriage. 66 Christian churches are attacked annually. Every year, 160 Christians are imprisoned without the right to stand trial.  Mr Jan Figen's task as the EU's special envoy to promote freedom of religion or belief outside the EU is not easy at all, but it has done so very responsibly over the past two and a half years. As much as he could within the possibilities he was given, and they are really not great.  The fact is that this mandate is only advisory. It is a contractual arrangement without regular salary, without staff and without a budget for work. I consider it essential to institutionally strengthen the mandate of the EU Special Envoy to promote freedom of religion or belief outside the EU. The lives of millions of Christians are at risk every day, they need concrete solutions and active actions from the EU. Words are just a blank letter on paper if they're not turned into works.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for the brief presentation of the report by Marisa Matias and Ernest Urtasun on gender equality and tax policies in the European Union (2018/2095(INI)))(A8-0416/2018).

name: Marisa Matias
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking Ernest Urtasun and the whole team that worked to make this report a reality. It was an honor to have worked with these people specifically. I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs of the different parliamentary groups for their contributions and willingness to negotiate.  Gender inequalities in the European Union are a sad reality. Several times in this House are addressed and numerous resolutions have been adopted that identify the various dimensions of inequality between men and women and appeal to their fight. But let's be realistic. To combat them you need to have a gender perspective in all policies and not just statements of intent that change nothing.  One of the key areas for this fight is taxation. Women are under-represented in the labour market, with an overall employment rate 12% lower than men's, and of women working, a third do so only part-time. The gender pay gap is 16 % and in retirement pensions this inequality is 40 %. Years and years of cumulative effect of the various disparities. Not only do they earn less, but women are the ones who interrupt their careers the most and are the women who are most dedicated to caring for their children or family members with disabilities or permanent support needs. In the European Union, 80% of care is provided by formal carers of whom 75% are women. Direct and indirect taxation policies are also unfavorable to women. The regressive policies we have seen in recent years with regard to the taxation of labour, societies, consumption or wealth have weakened the redistributive capacity of tax regimes and have resulted in an increase in income inequality, as well as a structural change in taxation that has shifted the tax burden to lower income groups, particularly affecting women. With this report, we present specific recommendations to governments to address these inequalities in four distinct areas. Firstly, in direct taxation, whether in the taxation of the income of natural persons, in the taxation of companies or in the taxation of capital and wealth. Secondly, in indirect taxation, in particular VAT schemes which burden women when goods of first necessity and hygiene continue to be taxed as if they were luxury goods. Third, the impact of tax evasion and avoidance that directly affect the resources available to public services promoting equality par excellence. Fourth, finally, the integration of gender equality into tax policies, notably through regular assessments of the impact of gender tax policies. In this report nothing is impossible to execute if there is a real political will for women and men to be treated equally. That is the signal that should be given by Parliament tomorrow when it votes on this proposal.

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to begin by paying tribute – before entering the matter – to Pawel Adamowicz – the mayor of Gdansk, who has just died killed as a result of yesterday's attack – a true defender of rights and freedoms in this Europe threatened by the emergence of dark forces. Your murder is a European tragedy, and I want to begin my speech today by paying tribute to you and saying that your fight for freedoms and rights is the fight, and it will continue to be the fight, of all. I would also like to begin by thanking Marisa Matias for the preparation of this report, as well as for the teams that have made it possible for us to put, for the first time, a central issue, such as taxation, at the heart of gender equality policies. We cannot follow another minute in such a fundamental area, that it defines our model of well-being and our resources and how we deal, how we raise and how we spend our resources, without this being done without any gender perspective. And it's important because it allows you to go on the offensive on a gender equality agenda that must be extremely ambitious. I have to say that in the four years I've been here, we've had an extremely timid equality agenda. Most of the equality directives are stopped in the Council, either the Directive on the representation of women on the boards of directors, or also the whole process we had to carry out with the withdrawal of the Maternity Leave Directive, and also the difficulties we are having with the ratification of the Istanbul Convention. We have had an extremely timid equality legislature. And we need to be aware that, at the moment, there are forces emerging in a brutal way at European Union level, that fundamental principles are being questioned, such as gender-based violence, by political formations that are having a lot of votes in the European Union, such as, for example, we have just seen in Andalusia. And, by the way, I would like to congratulate all the people who will take to the streets in Spain tomorrow, in solidarity with the Andalusian women, after the aberrant agreement reached, which is also for the participation of that party is a real shame in the face of equality of people. But these forces are putting the fundamentals into question. We cannot be re-discussing whether or not gender-based violence exists. We need to go on the offensive, with a gender equality agenda that is really ambitious, combating violence, combating wage inequalities and including new forms of discrimination that have never been addressed. For example, taxation, which is what this report is about. And so start having public policies that analyze how our tax systems, both in direct and indirect taxation, address inequality is very important. And this report, for example when we talk about the issue of direct taxation, sets out how in many Member States of the European Union we have seen that the obligation to do so, the possibility of making taxation on joint income discourages the second supplier of that declaration from entering the labour market. And that is direct discrimination that encourages women to have difficulties in accessing the labour market. Or, if we are talking about indirect taxation – and that many movements, in many countries, in France and in other countries have pointed out – how can it be that, at the moment, products that are of first need for women are charged with luxury VAT? This is absolutely intolerable. And also, another of the things that report points out, which is very important. Let's see what the different consumption patterns are between men and women. And if you look at them, it's very clear that women currently endure more VAT on average than men. Therefore, neither the European Semester nor all the debates we are having on taxation, which have been very important in this mandate, can continue to become absolutely blind to the issue of gender equality and taxation. And that is why this report, and with this I conclude, calls for us to tackle this phenomenon in an ambitious way in the next parliamentary term and to recover that ambitious and courageous gender equality agenda, which is what the European Union needs.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I understand the intention of colleagues who are trying to establish gender equality, who want to reduce the gender pay gap, but colleagues, this is not a good path that you have chosen. We cannot, for the sake of this objective, violate subsidiarity. Tax decision-making, the tax system, that is, above all, the competence of the Member States. And I will always be in favour of using, for example, family taxation, the right of families to benefit from tax rebates, after all, it is the best tool to help bring families to justice, to take advantage of women doing so, if a Member State has this tax advantage. This report goes in exactly the opposite direction. I am very sorry, for example, i respect my colleague Urtasuna, who is one of the few courageous men who is a member of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, but this is not a good solution.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, it’s deplorable that there is still a gender bias in our taxation system, and I’m happy that this report highlights particularly period poverty. It’s a real issue for women and girls across Europe and a fundamental concern. It’s awful that poverty prevents people from accessing the basic health products that they rely upon.  In Blackpool, in my constituency, local councillors have been supporting the Red Box Project to supply free sanitary products in schools. As 49% of respondents to a 2017 survey reported missing school due to their periods, the importance of free sanitary products is clear. Another survey in the northwest showed 44% of respondents had used toilet paper in place of sanitary products. Education and dignity shouldn’t be affected owing to zero access to basic health products.  I support removing VAT from these products to make them more affordable and call on Member States to ensure that there is access to free products in public spaces. I also call for the EU to push for more radical steps to make sanitary products free across the EU.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, tax policies affect citizens' incomes and, of course, they also affect gender equality as women are much more vulnerable in the economic sector. The first thing we should see is that aggressive tax planning must be stopped because in this way the various multinationals do not pay taxes where they make profits but in tax havens. The second issue is overtaxation, this applies in particular to Greece. Huge tax rates and tax plunder on the part of the troika in order for Greece to achieve the famous surpluses. That is, to give 3% of Greek GDP to lenders every year until 2022. In addition, an increased value added tax on basic foodstuffs, especially in the Aegean islands which are remote from mainly Greece. This really has the effect of increasing poverty and social exclusion and, much more so, the social exclusion of women. Specific measures must therefore be taken at the level of taxation.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: – Madame la Présidente, Madame la Commissaire, some groups in this House are able to make a legitimate subject of discussion even from topics that this House should no longer discuss on the principle of subsidiarity. The report presented on gender equality and tax policies in the EU is an example of this. I fundamentally reject all forms of indirect or direct discrimination against women. However, joint taxation of spouses is not directed against women. On the contrary, it favours families – women and men who are committed to mutual care and are willing to accept and eduate children. I also find it unfortunate to call for a majority vote in the Council on tax matters. Its adoption would create space for populists and nationalists to accuse us of betraying national sovereignty. We shouldn't admit that.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I do not want to downplay the subject, I certainly want to say that there are a number of very instructive examples and positive moments in the report. In general, I would like to stress that inequality can be observed in all ies in access to services, in the increasing income gap between men and women. Here I would like to sprinkle a little ash on my head, because the Czech Republic achieves a rather very significant income gap between men and women.  Of course, a woman and a man are equal partners to me. However, in the case of tax policy, it is clear that their revenues are simply shared, and that is what the report also points to. I think that we should determine that role, especially for the Member States, because they are the ones that have an irreplaceable role in this case, and they should create a social system, a tax system that is equivalent. That means building on that equal principle. I do not want to question the motivation of my colleagues why they have presented this report, but At the same time, I think that subsidiarity should play a more preferential role in this sense.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank you for placing the issue of gender equality and taxation on Parliament’s agenda. As was mentioned many times, taxation is a key element of public policy and is central to securing an efficient and stable economy in a fair and inclusive society.  Fairer taxation in the single market has been at the core of the Commission’s mandate. Also, gender equality is one of the fundamental values and objectives of the European Union. The current strategic engagement for gender equality includes a strong dimension aimed at mainstreaming gender policies throughout other Union policies, including taxation, without calling into question sovereignty and subsidiarity in this sphere. Parliament’s recommendations on how to take the gender perspective into account in taxation matters will contribute to modern tax policies capable of responding to the common challenges of an increasingly integrated economy with a clear social dimension. The importance of tax disincentives has been highlighted, especially in the Commission’s Communication on work-life balance which was adopted in April 2017. As set out in the Communication, the Commission has included the issue in the annual tax policy survey and considered it in the context of the analysis of labour taxation and its impact on inclusive growth. Supporting gender equality is an important element of the European Semester tool which is discussed in depth in many country reports. Several Member States received country-specific recommendations to tackle gender gaps in terms of employment rate and pay and pension levels.  This also covers addressing disincentives for second earners, usually women, to work or to work full time, including through taxation. This is currently identified as a challenge under the European Semester, notably for Germany and Belgium, to be specific. Taxation has furthermore a role to play in supporting gender equality, for example as a funding source of essential public services. In that context, we appreciate the support of Parliament. Direct tax policies cannot be based on the belief that households always pool and share their funds equally. On the other hand, indirect taxation depends on consumption patterns. It cannot be the aim of VAT or excise duties to encourage or discourage the consumption of specific products just because they are consumed more by either women or men.  Female hygienic products are obviously an exception. They are only consumed by women and they are a necessity. Therefore, Member States have the possibility to apply a reduced VAT rate to them, as they can do for food or care services.  That being said, the gender gap is often caused by a lack of adequate care services as well as working time arrangements or family leave, which allow those with care responsibilities to combine work with private life. Also, it is important to ensure an equal sharing of care responsibilities between men and women. Therefore, more needs to be done beyond tax policies to tackle gender equality. A comprehensive approach is needed based on a combination of legislative and non-legislative measures, and this is the approach of the Commission, for instance in our work-life balance package and the strategic engagement for gender equality. Let me conclude by emphasising that the Commission in its actions remains committed to promoting equal economic independence for women and men, closing the gender pay gap, which is still quite high in several Member States, advancing gender balance in decision-making and gender-based violence and promoting gender equality beyond the EU. Taxation is one of the important areas for achieving this.

name: La Présidente. –
text: This item on the agenda is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, January 15, 2019.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for the brief presentation of Wim van de Camp's report on autonomous vehicles in European transport (2018/2089 (INI)) (A8-0425/2018).

name: Wim van de Camp
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, to the extent that I have not yet done so, I wish everyone a happy New Year and a great deal of health in this election year. Firstly, I would like to thank my shadow rapporteurs, but above all the rapporteurs of the IMCO Committee and the Committee on Legal Affairs, both of whom have given a good opinion on my initiative report, which I will return to in a moment.  I would like to point out that this initiative report is not only about cars, but also about other means of transport, for example the metro, the train and the self-driving barges. This is an industrial development that we can certainly embrace. This is also a matter of European industrial policy, and in particular the spin-off to other sectors, as we have seen in space, is of great importance in the development of self-driving vehicles. This dossier is certainly also linked to the Europe 2030 innovation programme. At the same time, the united States, China, South Korea and even Israel are competitive here. They are all working to develop self-driving vehicles as soon as possible.  Another important aspect of this issue is road safety. I know that your colleague, Mrs Bulc, is very concerned about road safety: 90% of road accidents in Europe are caused by human error. When you talk about road safety, you also talk directly about the question of liability. Who is liable for the self-driving vehicle? And that is what our Committee on Legal Affairs has said valuable things about.  Another important point in this dossier is the psychology of the self-driving car. In other words, is the individual European citizen ready to surrender to a fully self-driving car? That will require some upheaval and some changeover from that citizen. I also call attention to the workers here. There are many employees in the automotive industry and associated companies who are concerned about their work on a fully self-driving vehicle.  I ask the Commission to pay special attention to the regulations. It is of the u-important importance that we in Europe should have one regulation so that self-driving vehicles, whether a train or a boat or a car, can leave the Member State without border problems. And I refer to the Amsterdam Declaration of 2016 and the work in Geneva to achieve world regulation.  Finally, the dates. There is a lot of discussion, including in the Committee on Transport, about data protection. On the one hand, we talk about the protection of personal data, the data of the car manufacturer and the data of the aftermarket. I invite the European Commission to develop a full balance for this.  Finally, of course, I invite the new Commission to include a good passage, a good chapter, on the development of self-driving vehicles within the European Union in the 2019-2024 programme.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I note, of course, that automated mobility has the potential for many sectors by offering new business opportunities for start-ups, of course SMEs, which are at the heart of our interest, and also for industry and businesses as a whole, particularly in terms of creating new mobility services, as well as the potential to create jobs , which, however, also has the potential to potentially reduce it. We deal with a number of legal aspects, safety and, for example, reliable route data. The issue of insurance, special insurance, we are solving the problem of vehicle overcrowding already on existing infrastructures, and this problem of overcrowding will not, of course, solve our autonomous traffic. The problem of cars in cities will remain. I undoubtedly support this traffic in public transport, but, as the rapporteur also said, there is still a lot of work to be done in the area of legislation, which, of course, must probably not be underestimate.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, autonomous driving in transport is indeed an important development which will de facto be imposed in the coming years. It is a given that the European Union is in competition with the United States, China and Japan, which are moving faster in autonomous driving. On the other hand, we must bear in mind that there are also very significant collateral damage, particularly social, particularly in the area of employment. All this must be taken into account in order to provide social support to those who, as technology develops in the field of autonomous driving, may lose their jobs. From then on there is a serious issue with safety during the transport process, which should also be taken seriously. So yes to the evolution of technology, yes to progress, but in a way that is safe and socially just.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Madam President, rapid development in the fields of robotics and technical intelligence gives us the ability and the ability to build on and implement a vision that has existed in the past regarding the automation of movement. Of course, this development will have several positive elements, such as increasing safety, reducing transport costs, increasing environmental protection and, in general, positively affecting our daily lives. In addition, however, there are also some problems, some difficulties and some risks that need to be addressed, such as safety in driving, cybersecurity, security and the protection of personal data, as well as the ability to control people's personal lives. In addition, there are both legal and social issues, such as the impact on jobs. The European Union must therefore implement and draw up an integrated automation programme.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: Mr President, autonomous vehicles will sooner or later have a profound impact on the way we move and the way we transport freight. The rapporteur has rightly included different modes of transport than cars in this initiative report, such as inland waterways, drones and metros. Autonomous vehicles of any kind will also provide new opportunities for intermodal transport.  I would like to take a moment to reflect on the information flows that will arise when using autonomous vehicles. The scope of the applications that may arise as a result of vehicles that can communicate with each other and their environment is not yet incalculable.  The concern for respect for privacy is an important issue. However, if we want everyone to benefit from digitisation, partial access to vehicle internal data in real-time is also required for third-party use for other applications. This can also lead to additional innovation.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the transport sector is changing very fast. We must act now to shape this change and to make European mobility more sustainable, safer and more accessible. Action is necessary if we are to make European industry more competitive and European jobs more secure. These realities are very well reflected in the report prepared by Mr van de Camp, which supports more action, including at EU level. Let me say a few words about how to achieve sustainability. Transport is a major contributor to both greenhouse gas emissions and air pollution. Our commitment to fighting climate change thus requires the decarbonisation of our mobility. Cooperative and automated mobility is part of the solution, as it enables smoother traffic flows. My thanks for your support for this objective. Now on road safety. Not so long ago, Vision Zero – no road fatalities on European roads by 2050 – seemed an ambitious but distant vision. With the adoption of the Commission strategy on cooperative intelligent transport systems, we have reached an important milestone. With Mobility Package III, in addition to our fresh, safe system approach for road safety, we proposed a strategy that should help make the EU a global leader in automated mobility. This strategy is based on three pillars. First, a legal framework that creates a single market for automated mobility. Second, financial support for a sector-wide approach to research and EU—wide deployment. And third, an in-depth assessment of the socio—economic and ethical aspects of automated mobility. Vehicles become increasingly clean, connected and automated and ultimately driverless, with zero-emissions. At the same time, citizens’ demands in terms of mobility are growing and their attitude to mobility is changing. They want to shift seamlessly between different transport modes and enjoy easy access to travel information. Vehicles can become an integral part of multi-model mobility, providing first- and last-mile services and inclusive solutions for the elderly, the disabled and young people. But before we get there, we need to tackle issues related – as you mentioned as well – to security, data protection, fair and equal access to data, liability and ethical implications and the integration of automated vehicles into existing traffic, public acceptance, and our Skills Agenda. To progress on all these issues, I would like to highlight three elements for the many actions we have defined. Creating a single platform for cooperative, connected and automated mobility where all stakeholders come together to advance our ambitious agenda. The second pillar is setting up a joint undertaking for this cooperative, connected and automated mobility combining public and private efforts to accelerate the development and deployment of innovative mobility solutions. I have noted, and I thank you for, your support on this as well. Third, we propose to revise EU rules on vehicle safety and provide the relevant EU framework for the approval of automated and connected vehicles. Here too, I would like to thank you for your support, but I really call for discussions on the legal text to be finalised by the end of this Parliament. We really have no time to waste. As you can see, the future of mobility and the place of the end-user in it are at the centre of our thinking and our actions. We must remember that mobility is the cornerstone of freedom of movement for people and goods, and it is fundamental to the smooth functioning of the European Union.

name: La Présidente. –
text: This item on the agenda is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, January 15, 2019. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: writing – The rapid development of digitisation and the technological progress of society increasingly raises the need to address the problems associated with the onset of automated road transport. In addition to road transport, the ideas of automated mobility penetrate into other areas, water, maritime and air transport logistics. Automated mobility will change all transport systems and will certainly bring many benefits to society and individuals. The entry of automated vehicles into the European market is expected from 2020. However, when reducing them to road transport, emphasis must be placed on ensuring that transport is safer, sustainable, accessible and taking into account the need to protect the environment and air.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for one-minute speeches on important political issues (Article 163 of the Internal Regulation).

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. Romania has taken over the Presidency of the European Union for the first time since its accession to the European Union. I am convinced that you will successfully address the extremely complex challenges of the coming months. The big question is whether a truly important political result will be achieved. Will Schengen accession succeed? Romania must join the Schengen area," President Juncker said in Bucharest. I call on those Member States that are preventing them from changing their positions," President Tajani said. However, the decision is in the hands of the Member States, which have been postponing our accession for eight years unduly for political reasons. The RMDSZ is calling for Romania's accession to Schengen, and we hope that this will happen as soon as possible. This is also in the interests of our Community and of the country and of the Union. This is how the lifting of today's double standard, with which Romania and the other Eastern European Member States are managed by the West, can begin. I wish you every success.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I am involved in highlighting the problem of a sector — that of Valencian citrus fruits — of great importance to my community, to Spain and to the European Union, because Valencia is the main exporting region of the Union, with a turnover of more than 2 billion euros, and now its 250 000 jobs are at risk of the crisis in the sector.  In the first two months of this campaign alone, more than EUR 130 million has been lost to adverse market conditions and to the low, very low prices paid to the producer. The sector needs solutions and I therefore ask the European institutions, first, for an assessment of the impact on Valencian citrus fruits of imports from third countries such as Egypt, South Africa or Turkey; harmonisation of customs controls to avoid unfair practices, and the urgent application of the new European legislation against the abuse of large intermediaries in pricing.  Europe needs to provide solutions because it needs its agriculture.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Madam President, last week the European Parliament's Committee on Transport and Tourism rejected two of the three proposals relating to the so-called 'transport and tourism' package or mobility package. With this, she acknowledged the complete insolvency of these proposals, their cynical nature, the attempt through a proposal by the European Parliament to steal the business of hundreds of thousands of Eastern entrepreneurs and entrepreneurs from the periphery in general.  These cynical proposals revealed the double standards in east-west relations. They uncovered the experience through non-market methods, through the obstruction of free competition, through a violation of the free market, of preventing carriers and workers from Eastern Europe and peripheral countries from being turned into immigrants.  This package is a failure, a proven failure. We demand that this package be withdrawn and considered in the next parliament. This parliament has exhausted its life, has no political weight and should not make decisions that affect hundreds of millions of people across the European continent.  I urge the Conference of Presidents to withdraw this package and not to vote on it now.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, the current question these days is what the European Union will bring to the European Union. Unfortunately, this matter is not just about anxiety on the one hand and enthusiasm on the other about the expected strengthening of Eurosceptic xenophobic parties. It is really about the credibility of the European Union, its added value. These days, we will be talking to the Spanish Prime Minister Sánchez about the future of Europe, just days before the start of the monstrosing process against Catalan political prisoners who have been in prison for a year and are threatened with draconian judgments, and we remain silent. These days, we will decide on our trade interests in Western Sahara and overlook that there are violations of international law and human rights. Do we have a Plan B for the crisis that is being indicated in Macedonia, to which we promised a European future? On these issues, our credibility is or falls, not on populist pre-election rhetoric.

name: Klaus Buchner (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It has been a year since the plenary of the European Parliament adopted the so-called dual-use regulation by a majority of 92%.  It is intended to restrict the export of surveillance technology to dictatorships. For it is European technology that contributes to the arrest of journalists and opponents of the regime in many parts of the world. I would just like to remind you of the Khashoggi case, Iran and then the collapse of the Arab Spring. This dual-use regulation has yet to be approved by the Council of Ministers.  But he has been refusing for a year. First it was the countries of Sweden and Finland – because of their companies Nokia and Ericsson – but now it is France. It is incomprehensible that France is refusing to stop the daily violations of human rights committed by means of European and, in particular, French technology, despite the passionate and professional efforts of the Romanian Presidency. I am very disappointed. The French Government must also uphold fundamental human rights.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, last month, this House approved a fund that will give EUR 13 billion to the European defence industry, covering the entire life cycle of deadly weapons from research to their use in action. This fund, supported by members of Fine Gael, will subsidise the same defence industries that are fuelling wars and humanitarian crises in Yemen and Syria, as well as deeply oppressive state surveillance techniques by some of the most brutal regimes in the world. Irish association with this fund will further breach our neutrality that has been systematically undermined by successive governments. Irish neutrality, if valued and respected, actually allows our country to play a positive and constructive role in international affairs. It means our defence forces can be real peacekeepers in UN missions and that we can use our own experience of enduring colonisation and occupation to advocate the resolution of conflict rather than the creation of war. Being part of the aggressive EU militarisation policy actually makes us less safe, inevitably connecting us to the worst actions of the forces that are part of it. Well, we want no part of it. It’s time to stand up for Irish neutrality.

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab What is happening in France today is the beginning of the end of Europe that is being tried to create here, the beginning of the end of this utopian vision of Europe. This is the effect of your detachment from reality, because such detachment from reality then ends sooner or later with such a violent event with this reality. You have the effect of your climate policy – that's where it started, the rebellion against fuel price increases. You have the effect of your economic policy, where you promise people pears on the willow. You promise that you will take care of everything. You try to interfere with the whole market, and then you can't deliver on those promises, and people expect that. People have already believed that the state is almighty, and now they are waiting for the symptoms of it. They do not understand that socialism is going bankrupt, but that is how any such socialist experiment must end. That's how the gagging of the mouth ends, the silence of public debate. It explodes with double force, and that's how permissive politics ends. States that abolish the death penalty are doomed, because then they can only shoot rubber bullets when their citizens' property is demolished.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 2019 began with a climate of heave tension between mainland China and Taipei Island. In the face of the denial of The President of the Republic of China in Taiwan, Tsai Ing-wen, regarding a peaceful reunification with communist China, President Xi Jinping renewed the threat of the use of military force to counter the interference of foreign forces and what he called a small number of Taiwanese separatists. These divisions become even more dangerous at a time when Taiwan could become a top in the trade and political war between China and the United States, threatening the security of the entire Asia-Pacific region where countries with nuclear capabilities exist, as is known. Although it has no formal diplomatic ties with Taiwan and endorses the one-China policy, it is with this island and not with mainland China that the European Union shares the same values of democracy, human rights rule of law and therefore cannot fail to condemn any attempt to determine the future Taiwan using non-peaceful means. I believe that the European Union has a moral obligation to support Taiwan at this difficult time in its collective history.

name: Giuseppe Ferrandino (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the processes of globalisation have given impetus to technological innovations in two key areas: communications and transport. It is easier than in the recent past in the European Union to move, both within and between individual Member States. However, there are still pockets of marked backwardness, the most marked being calabria. Getting out and getting back into it is difficult and costs more, both because of the weakness of the infrastructure and because of the scarcity of carriers. Calabria is isolated even from Rome, after Ryanair has cancelled its low-cost flights from Lamezia, Alitalia is the master on this route, with excessive costs: a one-way economy ticket costs about 160 euros. The train is also not feasible: Italo stops in Salerno and Trenitalia has too much costs. Reaching the capital from Lamezia at high speed costs over 80 euros in second class and this leads to a serious difference in treatment compared to the rest of the national territory since, for example, arriving from Rome to Milan costs about 44 euros. Is it possible that Calabria is cut off from the opportunities of progress?

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the withdrawal of US forces from Syria will have a serious impact on religious and ethnic minorities in the country. Turkey3s aggressive foreign policy surprises no one. Their politicians are verbally molesting and threatening their neighbours every day. We have witnessed a Turkish invasion on the southern border and we will see it again. 100 000 Christians and other minorities are on a deadly march from Turkish-led jihadists, who are waiting until US troops have left the country. Together with the Chaldeans-Syriacs-Assyrians Friendship Group, we call on the US administration to slow down the departure of US forces until the security of the Christians and all other people has been secured.  As a member of the Chaldeans-Syriacs-Assyrians Friendship Group, I appeal to NATO member states to encourage their Turkish partner not to invade the region and carry out violations against religious and ethnic minorities in north-east Syria. Moreover, a no-fly zone for north-east Syria must be established in order to let local militias, such as the Syriac Military Council, defend themselves against Turkish aggression.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, it has been three long years during which Bosnia and Herzegovina has not managed to adopt the rules of procedure for the work between our Parliament and theirs – three long years. During these three years we have been listening to a lot of stories about how we should adopt the ethnic rules of procedure. Our problem, Madam President, is that we see that the country doesn’t function with these rules. We don’t want to adopt them here, because neither we will function. If a country wants to join the European Union, they will have to adopt the rules that exist here. We have lost three years on this. Not a single meeting has been held, and I certainly hope that with the new political figures, the country will come up with a solution and overcome this blockade and start the real work, because many more important things and difficult things are awaiting us on the way to joining the EU.

name: Jordi Solé (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, the Spanish Government has refused Open Arms permission to continue saving lives in the Mediterranean. It cannot leave Barcelona on the perverse argument that, since Malta, Italy and Libya do not offer a safe harbor to disembark castaways, then it is not safe to rescue people and, therefore, states that violate international law, there can be no rescues. A perverse argument. They also say that the ship does not have enough capacity to carry a large number of people on board. As if this were a luxury cruise ship and not a vessel dedicated to saving castaways who, under international law itself, do not count as a ticket or as a crew. According to the United Nations, 2,275 people died in the Mediterranean last year. Do you think that with this drama we can afford to block ships whose only mission is to try to reduce so much human suffering?  With every port that closes, with every rescue ship that does not sail, with every migrant drowning, our European values are also sinking.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, at the beginning of the year, the Dutch daily Financieele Dagblad revealed that Google has transferred 20 billion euros to Bermuda. This unbearable fraud, at a time when so many of our citizens are struggling to finish the month or are deprived of public services, is taking billions of euros off the state budget every year. 1 trillion for the European Union, which should be used to finance schools, hospitals, transport, environmental transition, instead of filling the bank accounts of the minority of the richest 1%. After that, the Commission harasses states over their public deficit, banning them from any ambitious social policy. But the money is there, in these black holes of finance. That is why it is urgent that the Commission and the European Council, in conjunction with the OECD's international proposals, ban these practices and force multinationals and banks to return the stolen money and make them pay their fair share of contributions to the common good.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, exactly fifty years ago, student Jan Palach burned himself to death in Prague's Wenceslas Square. It was January 16, 1969. Three days later, he died of burns. Why?  It was so that we would not forget, he wanted to provoke czechs and Slovaks against occupation, against censorship, against the loss of the ideal of the Prague Spring. He wanted to galvanify the conscience of the nation into resistance. The strength of his protest struck the conscience and soul of Czechs and Slovaks, who then proudly returned to his legacy thirty years ago during the so-called Palach Week, when they protested against the then Communist dictatorship.  Jan Palach sacrificed his life, but it was not in vain, because we now live in freedom, in the community of European nations. But even today, his victim is up to date, because even today, lies and intimidation are spreading. That's why we need to remember his sacrifice today.

name: Alex Mayer (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the people over there told us that Brexit would be easy – easy trade deals, easy frictionless borders, easy money for our NHS. What arrant nonsense that turned out to be. Because now we have it, brought to us by the government that have given a ferry contract to a company with no ferries and can’t even organise a traffic jam: the deal that means that we get stuck abiding by the rules, but with no say over making them and pay billions in a divorce bill but have no guarantees for the future. It’s bad for manufacturers of vans in Luton, it’s bad for passengers flying in and out of Stansted Airport, it’s bad for the world-class researchers at Cambridge University. We have bartered, swapped and traded real power for notional sovereignty, and I say: not in my name. So my message to MPs of all political colours voting in the House of Commons is to vote down this miserable deal. Extend Article 50 and end this national humiliation.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, Chancellor Angela Merkel, with her visit to Athens, challenged the Greek people both by her refusal to pay German reparations and by her pressure to implement the despicable agreement of the Prespas, an agreement that sells out the name of our Macedonia and our history and reinforces intransigence and purposeful altruism. The Greek people do not tolerate humiliation and react en masse as they see Mr. Tsipras methodically forming a heterogeneous parliamentary majority of "kourel" in order to obtain a vote of confidence and ratify the agreement of the Prespas. All this because he dares not hold a referendum on the Skopje as the Greeks demand. It methods ratification of the Agreement of the Prespas with various political "retalia" and with 151 Deputies, while according to the Constitution 180 votes are required for ratification since this agreement assigns sovereign rights to the Macedonians. But Mr. Tsipras plans without the Greek people united to send a decisive message en masse, peacefully and democratically to the Constitution rally on Sunday, January 20th.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the same history is often repeated throughout Europe. a multinational is installed in one territory because of the great advantages and facilities it receives and, once they are exhausted, closes to produce elsewhere with lower labor and environmental costs.  This is the case today of the American multinational Alcoa, which has announced the closure of its plants in Spain to move its aluminum production to Saudi Arabia. And he wants to close, he doesn't want to sell, because he doesn't want to have competition for his new factory. There are seven hundred direct jobs that are at risk, to which we must add the future of the communities where their factories are based.  That is why, since the works councils are asking, and also from our political group we are asking the Government of Spain to use the constitutional mechanisms to stop the closure of the factories of Coruña and Avilés through public intervention of the State, in whole or in part, temporary or indefinite, but to ensure that employment will continue , that these plants are going to continue and that you will avoid the drama that is happening.

name: László Tőkés (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. Despite President Juncker's serious doubts about Romania's readiness for the EU Presidency and, on the other hand, the European Parliament condemning our country in plenary debates and by decision for serious violations of the democratic rule of law, on the occasion of the takeover of the EU Presidency, on the occasion of the fourth of January in Bucharest, the eu's main dignitaries spoke in superlatives about the successful Romanian Presidency that had been prepared. In May this year, Pope Francis will also visit Romania. With his high-profile visit, he legitimises, unwittingly, the post-communist system in Romania, the romanian government's corrupt policy of disenfranchiseing ethnic and religious minorities, in line with european top leaders. In this regard, the Roman Catholic Church's resolution in September that, where fundamental human and minority and sectarian rights are violated, the conditions for the pope's visit are not ensured.

name: Maria Gabriela Zoană (S&D).
text: – Commissioner, I have taken note with concern of a decision taken by the Austrian Parliament affecting thousands of families and children in Romania and other Eastern European countries and in breach of both the European rules in force and the principles of equality and non-discrimination within the European Union. More than 130 000 European children are affected, Commissioner. Austria is in breach of Article 21 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. Austria's Parliament is turning the children of European citizens into children of different ranks. It is unacceptable in a European Union as we all want it. Citizens of other European countries working in Austria pay the same taxes as Austrian workers. In those circumstances, why would they receive a total of around EUR 100 million less for child benefit from the Austrian State? Isn't this a violation of the principles of labour law? Is this not a violation of the rights of European citizens? I call on you, fellow Members, to take urgent action to penalise non-compliance with European rules and to return to compliance with them.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, once again we find companies which, receiving substantial subsidies and aid, close their production centres as the only answer to some difficulty. I am referring to companies like Alcoa, more than 700 affected workers. Vodafone, 1,200 jobs pending an employment regulation dossier. Endesa and its announcement of the closure of Andorra's thermal by 2020, without an alternative plan for an unpopulated region. Companies put their business plans before employment. But it is the governments – the Government of Spain – that must adopt solutions that go through a productive model where the weight of industrial GDP grows; with the budget increase in R&D&I; with public companies in strategic sectors of the economy and the repeal of labour reforms promoted by different European institutions. Since the beginning of the crisis, workers have suffered the consequences of their misguided policies. This is not the way. Start implementing economic and social measures that put workers at the centre of action.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. In the first half of this year, Romania holds the presidency of the Council of the European Union and unfortunately, 12 years after the country's accession to the EU, we still need to talk about the fact that the other Member States are not allowing Romania and Bulgaria into the Schengen area. This situation is extremely undignified, as the European Commission indicated as early as 2011 that the two countries were ready to join, took the necessary steps to strengthen border protection and were able to protect the external borders of the region, unlike other States in the Schengen area. By arbitrarily blocking the extension of the Schengen area without any formal justification, some Member States are sending a message to the approximately 25 million EU citizens living in the two countries that they are seen as second-class citizens who do not even deserve a fair explanation of the situation. It would be important for governments opposed to the accession of Romania and Bulgaria to Schengen to take their decision and publicly justify it, because if something destroys cohesion within the EU, then this situation will certainly do so.

name: Răzvan Popa (S&D).
text: – The President, as is well known, Austria has recently adopted and started to apply legislation on allowances for non-resident children. In other words, from now on, in Austria, Romanian citizens who work in this country but do not have their children by their side will be discriminated against. Although Romanians working in Austria pay taxes like Austrian citizens, their children's allowances will be reduced at the level of their home state, which means a regime of discrimination that should not be accepted in Europe – and it is not just Romanians, but all citizens of the other European Union countries working in Austria. Such a decision violates a fundamental social and economic principle: equal contributions and work, benefits should be equal. But behold, a European state, Austria, refuses to respect this principle anymore. Such policies are precisely those that affect the cohesion of the European project and citizens' confidence in it. I call on the European Commission to take the necessary measures as a matter of urgency so that Romanian citizens in Austria are not victims of discriminatory policies incompatible with European values.

name: John Howarth (S&D).
text: – Madam President, recent weeks have seen increasing attempts at intimidation of Members of Parliament in the United Kingdom. The Metropolitan Police have now arrested one of those filmed harassing Anna Soubry MP, a prominent Conservative opponent of Brexit. Those involved appear to have direct links to far-right groups associated with Stephen Christopher Yaxley-Lennon, a convicted violent criminal who now goes under the alias Tommy Robinson. This thug (to quote Nigel Farage) has now been appointed by the UKIP leader Gerard Batten MEP as a special political adviser. These are disturbing developments at a delicate time. Let us not forget that during the 2016 Brexit referendum, a Labour MP, Jo Cox, was murdered in her constituency by an assailant shouting ‘Britain first’. Today I have written to the five chief constables in South-East England, urging that they ensure that harassment of Members of Parliament is not tolerated and our democracy and rule of law is protected.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, going on hunger strike is a decision not taken lightly, yet there is increased use of this desperate measure as a form of ethical protest. I have just returned from Diyarbakir where the imprisoned HDP MP Leyla Güven is in a critical condition after refusing food for 67 days in protest at the inhuman policy of isolation that Turkish authorities have long imposed upon Kurdish leader Abdullah Öcalan in Imrali jail. Leyla has been imprisoned herself for nearly a year awaiting trial because she criticised Turkish attacks on Afrin – which we also did here in this House. I can speak freely, but Leyla and hundreds of others cannot. Meanwhile, in a prison near Tehran, Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, a wrongfully jailed British charity worker, and Narges Mohammadi, an Iranian human rights defender, are beginning a hunger strike in protest at denial of medical care. Desperate times provoke desperate measures. But is the world listening? I call on the media to shine a light on these cases and provoke outrage amongst decent people.

name: La Présidente. –
text: This item on the agenda is closed.
